page.title: Grand Ducal Council of San Francisco

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Community-based organizations to [[:Category:Community organizations]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 April 10]].
revision.text:
{{notability|date=February 2017}} [[File:GrandDucalSF.jpg|thumb]] [[File:Currentmonarchs.jpg|thumb|Their Most Sovereign Majesties Grand Duchess Olivia Hart & Grand Duke Aja Monet-Ashton of San Francisco, Marin, and San Mateo counties]]
The '''Grand Ducal Council of San Francisco''',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.abebooks.com/Grand-Duke-Duchess-San-Francisco-ball/19949624351/bd|title=Grand Duke of Grand Duchess of San Francisco ball by Coronation] Douglas Mosher, photograph: Grand Ducal Council of San Francisco, San Francisco - Bolerium Books Inc.|website=www.abebooks.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sfbaytimes.com/kippy-marks-for-grand-duke/|title=Kippy Marks for Grand Duke - San Francisco Bay Times|date=2013-09-19|newspaper=San Francisco Bay Times|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://hoodline.com/2014/03/voting-for-2014-pride-grand-marshals-has-begun|title=Voting For 2014 Pride Grand Marshals Has Begun! {{!}} Hoodline|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref> Inc., is a predominantly [[gay]] 501(c)(3)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.guidestar.org/profile/94-3191460|title=Council of Grand Dukes and Grand Duchesses of San Francisco Inc - GuideStar Profile|website=www.guidestar.org|language=en|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref> nonprofit fund raising organization. Formed in 1973 as a more [[Camp (style)|camp]]-oriented response to San Francisco's [[Imperial Court System]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.impcourt.org/|title=impcourt.org - International Court System - Home|website=www.impcourt.org|language=en-us|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thetaskforce.org/postage-stamp-to-commemorate-harvey-milk/|title=Postage stamp to commemorate Harvey Milk - National LGBTQ Task Force|date=2013-10-15|newspaper=National LGBTQ Task Force|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref> by H.L. Perry, who reigned as the Court's Grand Duchess I,<ref name="Provenzano">{{cite news|url=https://m.facebook.com/groups/119840772836?view=info&refid=18|title=The Life and Times of H.L. Perry|last=Provenzano|first=Jim|date=2006-09-21|work=[[Bay Area Reporter]]|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref> the Grand Ducal Council raises money for a wide array of charity organizations through large annual costume balls and various other, smaller fund raisers throughout the year.<ref name="Pratt">{{cite news|url=http://www.sfbaytimes.com/index.php?sec=article&article_id=11107|title=Ducal Council to Crown First Miss SF Goldrush |last=Pratt|first=Paul|date=2009-07-16|work=[[San Francisco Bay Times]]|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref> Both the Imperial Court System and the Grand Ducal Council of San Francisco are built using roughly the same power structure. "Monarchs" are elected and the nonprofit, 501(c)(3) portion is run by a Board of Directors or Trustees.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfducal.org/Themes/BOD/BOD.htm|title=SFDucal.org: Royal Board of Directors|accessdate=2009-09-30}}</ref>
The Grand Ducal Council of San Francisco, in turn, inspired similar such organizations to be founded around the country. In 1998, the Grand Ducal Council of San Francisco was joined by a sister Court located in Alameda County, on the opposite side of the San Francisco Bay.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.alamedaducal.net/info.html |title=Alameda Ducal: Who We Are |accessdate=2009-09-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922222916/http://www.alamedaducal.net/info.html |archivedate=September 22, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfbaytimes.com/?sec=article&article_id=8682|title=Pollo Hits the Alameda Ducal Coronation |last=Del Mar|first=Pollo|date=2008-07-24|work=[[San Francisco Bay Times]]|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref> A third such sovereign Ducal Court exists in London, Ontario, Canada.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.impcourt.org/icis/chapters/london.html |title=ImperialCourt.org |accessdate=2009-10-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090929025558/http://www.impcourt.org/icis/chapters/london.html |archivedate=2009-09-29 |df= }}</ref>
Called "one of the city's unsung gay heroes," in 2006 HL Perry, her work establishing the San Francisco Ducal Council and more were commemorated with a month-long exhibit at the San Francisco Public Library.<ref name="Provenzano"/>
==Structure==
Each individual court chapter (or "realm") is a separate, legally incorporated charitable [[non-profit organization]] that raises funds and awareness for various charities and people in need within its realm. Each chapter has its own [[board of directors]] and is financially responsible for its own management. In addition to local non-profit status, many courts in the United States have [[U.S. government|Federal]] [[501(c)]] status.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}}
== Titles ==
Each court holds an annual "[[coronation]]," which is usually the chapter's largest fundraiser and is attended by both local members and members of other Ducal chapters as well Imperial Courts from across North America. The evening culminates in the ceremony in which the new monarch or monarchs—the Grand Duke and Grand Duchess—are crowned. In San Francisco, the new monarchs are determined by popular elections held in the community.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfbaytimes.com/index.php?sec=article&article_id=11309|title=Pollo Is Back on the Campaign Trail |last=Del Mar|first=Pollo|date=2009-09-20|work=[[San Francisco Bay Times]]|accessdate=2009-09-30}}</ref>
Within a set number of weeks, the newly elected monarchs must hold an "[[investiture]]," at which time they name the members of their Court.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ebar.com/arts/art_article.php?sec=outabout&article=98|title=Blast from the Past @LGBT Center|last=Provenzano|first=Jim|date=2006-11-09|work=[[Bay Area Reporter]]|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref> The titles given to members vary from one chapter to another and are primarily left to the discretion of the reigning monarchs.
Each Court consists of a [[Royal Crown Prince]] and [[Royal Crown Princess]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ebar.com/arts/art_article.php?sec=onthetown&article=65|title=In the Socializing Life|last=Sachet|first=Donna|date=2007-08-23|work=[[Bay Area Reporter]]|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref> Prince/Princess Royale, [[Baron]]/[[Baroness]], etc. Additionally, each year the Court holds fund raising competitions to crown such titles as Royal Baby Girl & Baby Boy, King & Queen of Hearts, Mr. & Miss Royal Bunny, Royal Daddy & Royal Daddy's Boy and White Knight and Debutante.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ebar.com/common/inc/article_print.php?sec=outabout&article=230|title=Queer & Far|last=Provenzano|first=Jim|date=2008-06-12|work=[[Bay Area Reporter]]|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref><ref name="ebar.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.ebar.com/common/inc/article_print.php?sec=outabout&article=102|title=St. Nicholas' Cotillion @Mr. Lee-Ona's|last=Provenzano|first=Jim|date=2006-12-07|work=[[Bay Area Reporter]]|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref> In 2009, the Court added an annual fund raising pageant to crown Miss San Francisco Gold Rush.<ref name="Pratt"/>
== Fundraising == Each court conducts numerous fundraisers throughout the year. Drag shows, ranging in size from performances at local bars to events in hotel ballrooms and other large venues, are the main way in which revenue is raised for charity.<ref name="ebar.com"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ebar.com/arts/art_article.php?sec=inthebars&article=18|title=Its No Rumor: The Club's a Hotspot|last=Sher|first=Mike|date=2005-12-22|work=[[Bay Area Reporter]]|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref> Especially in recent years, court chapters have diversified their fundraising strategies so as to include [[yard sales]], gift [[raffle]]s, etc.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ebar.com/common/inc/article_print.php?sec=outabout&article=239|title=Skin Is In!|last=Provenzano|first=Jim|date=2008-08-15|work=[[Bay Area Reporter]]|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref> Court members also solicit donations at [[LGBT]] events, [[gay pride parades]] and other public events at which they appear.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}}
The Grand Ducal Council of San Francisco donates the funds raised to a variety of causes including those related to [[AIDS]], [[breast cancer]], [[domestic abuse]], and [[homelessness]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ebar.com/artscolumns/artcolumn.php?sec=onthetown&id=20|title=Splashy Parties & Bubbly Company|last=Sachet|first=Donna|date=2006-02-09|work=[[Bay Area Reporter]]|accessdate=2009-10-04}}</ref>
== Membership ==
While composed primarily of [[gay]] and [[transgender]] as well as [[lesbian]], [[bisexual]] and [[transwomen]], each court is open to all. Gay, [[bisexuality|bisexual]], [[transgender]] and [[heterosexual|straight]] people have all served as monarchs and court members in the system's history.<ref name="in">[http://www.impcourt.org/icis/about/intro.html] Introduction to the Imperial Court System {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090103060749/http://www.impcourt.org/icis/about/intro.html |date=January 3, 2009 }}</ref> [[Drag queen]]s collectively comprise about half of the membership.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.SFDucal.org Grand Ducal Council of San Francisco Website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Grand Ducal Council Of San Francisco}} [[Category:Community organizations]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in California]] [[Category:LGBT events in California]] [[Category:LGBT organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Drag events]]

page.title: Impact of the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami on the video game industry

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} The '''[[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|2011 Tōhoku earthquake]]''' had a significant impact on the nation of Japan, including one of its most well-known exports, '''[[video game industry|video games and gaming consoles]]'''. The damage to Japan's infrastructure prompted delays in software and hardware releases, and also caused outright cancellations when the subject matter of the software was considered too similar to real-life events. At the same time, the Japanese gaming industry took on relief efforts to assist those most directly affected by the earthquake and subsequent [[tsunami]].
Members of the gaming industry contributed donations to support foundations including several large donations from video game-oriented companies such as [[Nintendo]], [[Sony Computer Entertainment]], [[Namco Bandai]], [[Sega Sammy]], [[Capcom]], and [[Tecmo Koei]], and have also encouraged donations from individuals. Several online games helped donate money to the relief effort, including ''[[EVE Online]]'' and [[Zynga]]'s Facebook games. Thirty-six hours after the initial tremor, Zynga has gathered donations adding up to $1.35 million.
==Background== {{main|2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami}} {{Location map+|Japan|width=250|float=right|border=#CCCCCC|caption=Map showing the epicenter of the earthquake|places= {{Location map~|Japan|lat=38.322|long=142.369|mark=Bullseye1.png|marksize=60|position=top}} {{Location map~|Japan|lat=35.7|long=139.715|label=Tokyo|position=left|mark=Green pog.svg}} {{Location map~|Japan|lat=38.26|long=140.87|label=Sendai|position=left|mark=Green pog.svg}}}}
A 9.0-[[moment magnitude scale|magnitude]] [[megathrust earthquake]] occurred off the coast of Japan on 11 March 2011.<ref name="USGS9.0">{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqinthenews/2011/usc0001xgp/ |title=Magnitude 9.0 – Near The East Coast Of Honshu, Japan |publisher=United States Geological Survey (USGS) |accessdate=13 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5x7WfsrXn?url=http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqinthenews/2011/usc0001xgp/ |archivedate=12 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="New Scientist">{{cite journal|url=https://www.newscientist.com/blogs/shortsharpscience/2011/03/powerful-japan-quake-sparks-ts.html|title=Japan's quake updated to magnitude 9.0 |edition = Short Sharp Science |journal=[[New Scientist]] |date=11 March 2011|first=Michael|last=Reilly|accessdate=11 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="New USGS number puts Japan quake at 4th largest">{{cite news|title=New USGS number puts Japan quake at 4th largest|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/03/14/501364/main20043126.shtml|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|date=14 March 2011|accessdate=15 March 2011 }}</ref> The [[epicenter]] was {{convert|130|km|sp=us}} off the east coast of the [[Oshika Peninsula]] of [[Tōhoku region|Tōhoku]] near [[Sendai]], with the [[hypocenter]] at a depth of {{convert|32|km|abbr=on|sigfig=3}}.<ref>{{cite news|title=Séisme et tsunami dévastateurs: plus de 1000 morts et disparus au Japon|url = http://www.leparisien.fr/tsunami-pacifique/seisme-et-tsunami-devastateurs-plus-de-1000-morts-et-disparus-au-japon-11-03-2011-1352998.php|newspaper=[[Le Parisien]] | date =11 March 2011|accessdate=12 March 2011|language= French|trans-title=Devastating quake and tsunami: more than 1,000 deaths and many more missing in Japan}}</ref><ref name="BBC1">{{cite news|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12709598|work=BBC News |title= Tsunami hits north-eastern Japan after massive quake| date =11 March 2011| location = UK | accessdate=11 March 2011}}</ref> The earthquake triggered extremely destructive [[tsunami]] waves of up to {{convert|10|m|sp=us}} that struck Japan minutes after the quake, in some cases traveling up to {{convert|10|km|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} inland,<ref>{{cite news|author=Roland Buerk|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12709598 |title= Japan earthquake: Tsunami hits north-east |publisher=BBC | work=News | location = UK |date= 11 March 2011|accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref> with smaller waves reaching many other countries after several hours. [[Tsunami warning]]s were issued and evacuations ordered along Japan's [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] coast and at least 20 other countries, including the entire Pacific coast of North America and South America.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=http://ptwc.weather.gov/text.php?id=pacific.2011.03.11.073000|title=Tsunami bulletin number 3|publisher=Pacific Tsunami Warning Center/NOAA/NWS|date=11 March 2011|accessdate=11 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite news|author=Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/03/11/tsunami.warning/index.html |title=Tsunami warnings issued for at least 20 countries after quake | publisher=CNN |date=11 March 2011 |accessdate=11 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url= http://ptwc.weather.gov/text.php?id=pacific.2011.03.11.103059 |title=PTWC warnings complete list | accessdate=11 March 2011}}</ref>
[[File:An aerial view of tsunami damage in an area north of Sendai, Japan, taken from a U.S. Navy helicopter.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Aftermath of the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] that took place near [[Tōhoku| Tōhoku, Japan]].]]
The Japanese [[National Police Agency (Japan)|National Police Agency]] officially confirmed a large number of casualties across seventeen [[Prefectures of Japan|prefectures]].<ref name="Template:2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami casualties NPA">{{cite news|title=Damage Situation and Police Countermeasures associated with 2011Tohoku district – off the Pacific Ocean Earthquake|url=http://www.npa.go.jp/archive/keibi/biki/higaijokyo_e.pdf|accessdate=17 March 2011|publisher=Japanese National Police Agency|date=17 March 2011<!--, 14:00 JST-->}}</ref><ref name="Template:2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami casualties NPA-JP">{{cite news|title=平成23年(2011年)東北地方太平洋沖地震の被害状況と警察措置|url=http://www.npa.go.jp/archive/keibi/biki/higaijokyo.pdf|accessdate=17 March 2011|publisher=Japanese National Police Agency|date=17 March 2011<!--, 14:00 JST-->|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170106143349/http://www.npa.go.jp/archive/keibi/biki/higaijokyo.pdf|archivedate=6 January 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The earthquake and tsunami caused extensive and severe damage in Japan, including heavy damage to roads and railways as well as fires in many areas, and a dam collapse. Around 4.4 million households in northeastern Japan were left without electricity and 1.5 million without water.<ref name="waterfoodheat">{{cite news|title=Millions Of Stricken Japanese Lack Water, Food, Heat|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/03/18/134527591/millions-of-stricken-japanese-lack-water-food-heat|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=16 March 2011|author=NPR Staff and Wires|date=14 March 2011|quote=Nearly 1.5 million households had gone without water since the quake struck.}}</ref> Many electrical generators were taken down, and at least three [[nuclear reactor]]s suffered explosions due to hydrogen buildup within their outer containment buildings.<ref>{{cite web|work=IAEA|date=16 March 2011|accessdate=16 March 2011|title=IAEA Update on Japan Earthquake|url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/tsunamiupdate01.html}}</ref>
Estimates of the [[Tōhoku]] earthquake's magnitude make it the most powerful known [[List of earthquakes in Japan|earthquake to hit Japan]], and one of the five [[Largest earthquakes by magnitude|most powerful earthquakes in the world]] overall since modern record-keeping began in 1900.<ref name="New USGS number puts Japan quake at 4th largest"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/13/japan-tsunami-earthquake-power-cuts |title=Tsunami, earthquake, nuclear crisis – now Japan faces power cuts |last=Branigan |first=Tania |date=13 March 2011 |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=15 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xDAT05x0?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/13/japan-tsunami-earthquake-power-cuts/print |archivedate=15 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="3news">{{cite news|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Japan-quake---7th-largest-in-recorded-history/tabid/417/articleID/201998/Default.aspx|title=Japan quake – 7th largest in recorded history|accessdate=11 March 2011|date=11 March 2011|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/5xtOn8fYs?url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Japan-quake---7th-largest-in-recorded-history/tabid/417/articleID/201998/Default.aspx#|archive-date=12 April 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Japanese Prime Minister [[Naoto Kan]] said that the crisis was the country's "toughest and most difficult" since [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/03/13/japan.quake/index.html?iref=NS1 | title=Japanese PM: 'Toughest' crisis since World War II | publisher=CNN | work=[[CNN International]] | date=13 March 2011 |accessdate=13 March 2011}}{</ref> The earthquake moved [[Honshu]] {{convert|2.4|m|ft|abbr=on}} east and shifted the Earth on its axis by almost {{convert|10|cm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Deutsche Welle">{{cite news|title=Quake shifted Japan by over two meters|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,14909967,00.html|work=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=14 March 2011|accessdate=14 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/14/world/asia/14seismic.html | title = Quake Moves Japan Closer to U.S. and Alters Earth's Spin | author=Kenneth Chang |work=The New York Times | date = 13 March 2011 | accessdate =14 March 2011 }}</ref> Early estimates placed insured losses from the earthquake alone at US$14.5 to $34.6 billion.<ref>{{cite news|author=Molly Hennessy-Fiske|work=Los Angeles Times |date=13 March 2011|accessdate=13 March 2011|title=Japan earthquake: Insurance cost for quake alone pegged at $35 billion, AIR says|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fgw-japan-quake-insurance-20110314,0,866931.story}}</ref> The [[Bank of Japan]] offered [[Japanese yen|¥]]15 trillion (US$183 billion) to the banking system on 14 March 2011 in an effort to normalize market conditions.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20110314/wl_nm/us_japan_quake |title=New explosion shakes stricken Japanese nuclear plant |last=Uranaka |first=Taiga |author2=Kwon, Ki Joon |date=14 March 2011 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=15 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xD9XGJub?url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20110314/wl_nm/us_japan_quake/print |archivedate=15 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Effects on business== The disaster resulted in a drop in stocks at the [[Tokyo Stock Exchange]] for many video game companies at the Monday close following. [[Eurogamer]]'s Gamesindustry.biz website reported that Sega Sammy's dropped 13.5 percent, ending up at ¥1530; Tecmo Koei's fell 10.7 percent to ¥626; [[Konami]]'s fell 9.9 percent to ¥1610; Sony's fell 9.1 percent to ¥2550; Nintendo's fell 7.6 percent to ¥21,280; Namco Bandai's fell 6.4 percent to ¥905; and [[Square Enix]]'s fell 6.2 percent to ¥1370.<ref name="gibiz"/> ''[[Edge magazine|Edge]]'' also reported drops, but lower amounts for Sega Sammy, Nintendo, and Square Enix: 1.3 percent, 1.1 percent, and 4.5 percent, respectively. Capcom's shares fell 14.4 percent, and the company announced closures of ten [[Video arcade|amusement arcades]] in the Tōhoku and [[Kantō region|Kantō]] regions due to damage.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.next-gen.biz/news/game-industry-hit-nikkei-slumps| archive-url = https://archive.is/20120908191231/http://www.next-gen.biz/news/game-industry-hit-nikkei-slumps| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 8 September 2012| title = Game Industry Hit As Nikkei Slumps| first = Nathan| last = Brown| publisher = Edge| date = 14 March 2011| accessdate = 21 March 2011}}</ref> The top 20 titles sold around 568,000 units between 6 and 12 March. In the same time period, the top 10 video game systems sold close to 195,000 units. Anoop Gantayat writing for IGN, however, speculated that most video game sales in Japan stopped when the earthquake occurred.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://ps3.ign.com/articles/115/1156231p1.html| title = Dynasty Warriors 7 Tops the Charts in Japan| publisher=IGN| date = 17 March 2011| first = Anoop| last = Gantayat| accessdate =21 March 2011}}</ref> [[Gamasutra]]'s Tom Cutris noted that most titles on Japan's charts dropped in sales the following week; the top 20 titles sold approximately 275,000 units. He further noted that the top seller, ''[[Dynasty Warriors 7]]'', sold 75 percent fewer copies compared to the previous week, when it debuted at number one.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/33689/Dynasty_Warriors_7_Holds_Lead_On_Japanese_Sales_Charts.php| title = Dynasty Warriors 7 Holds Lead On Japanese Sales Charts| publisher=Gamasutra| first = Tom| last = Curtis| date = 24 March 2011| accessdate =25 March 2011}}</ref>
No employees of Japan's gaming community have been reported as casualties of the quake or the subsequent tsunami.<ref name="USAT">{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gamehunters/post/2011/03/land-of-video-game-giants-japan-hit-by-earthquake-tsunami-social-networks-deliver-updates-/1 |title=Land of video game giants, Japan hit by earthquake, tsunami; social networks deliver updates – Game Hunters: In search of video games and interactive awesomeness |publisher=USAtoday |date=11 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |first=Mike |last=Snider}}</ref> IGN writers noted that most video game companies are a "significant distance" from the earthquake's epicenter.<ref name="IGN-Quake">{{cite web| url = http://games.ign.com/articles/115/1155124p1.html| title = Japanese Developers Largely Unharmed By Massive Earthquake| publisher=IGN| first1 = Richard| last1 = George| first2 = Anoop| last2 = Gantayat| first3 = Brian| last3 = Miggels| date = 11 March 2011| accessdate =23 March 2011}}</ref> Soon after the disaster struck, rumors began circulating that ''[[Pokémon]]'' series creator [[Satoshi Tajiri]], among other Japanese celebrities, had died in the tsunami; however, this turned out to be false when he tweeted that he was, in fact, alive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/215237/technology/japanese-stars-survive-quake-tsunami-but-not-twitter |title=Japanese stars survive quake, tsunami – but not Twitter |publisher=Gmanews |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> Several artists and designers used their online presences on social networking sites to provide information not only on their own situations, but to inform others of the disaster's impact. [[Hideo Kojima]], [[Masahiro Sakurai]], [[Goichi Suda]] and [[Fumito Ueda]] used their Twitter accounts to pass on information, with Suda encouraging his colleagues to seek shelter.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ashcraft |first=Brian |url=http://www.kotaku.com.au/2011/03/earthquake-crisis-brings-out-the-best-in-japan%E2%80%99s-gaming-greats/ |title=Earthquake Crisis Brings Out The Best In Japan's Gaming Greats |publisher=Kotaku |date=11 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> Kojima announced that he would be leaving his offices for power saving reasons.<ref name="msnbc"/> ''[[Ace Attorney]]'' series art director [[Tatsuro Iwamoto]] illustrated an image of characters from the series saying "Let's work hard and not be defeated by the earthquake!!".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tinycartridge.com/post/3855387959/phoenix-wright-miles-edgeworth-and-maya-fey |title=Phoenix Wright, Miles Edgeworth, and Maya Fey... |publisher=Tiny Cartridge |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> [[Nintendo|Nintendo's]] American subsidiary in [[Redmond, Washington|Redmond]], Washington provided updates on the status of the company headquarters and its employees.<ref name="USAT"/>
===Delays and cancellations=== When asked if the [[Nintendo 3DS]]' launch in Europe and North America would be affected by the situation, Nintendo gave indication that the former will be unaffected. It elaborated that business operations and future product shipments would be unaffected.<ref name="gibiz"/> Video games analyst [[Michael Pachter]] commented that it was difficult to assess how much impact the disaster will have, commenting that a company like Nintendo will not suffer as many set backs in the release of software as other companies have, such as Sony. He noted that if the threat of a nuclear plant meltdown grows stronger, the industry could be placed in much more dire straits. Pachter also noted that while Japanese software delays would not impact the United States market, hardware shortages could.<ref name="msnbc"/> Related hardware manufacturing industries have also indirectly affected video gaming. For example, Japan's manufacturers make up 70% of world's supply of [[anisotropic conductive film]]s for [[LCD]] production, and can, among other devices, affect [[Nintendo DS]] panel production.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.electronicsnews.com.au/news/japan-2011-earthquake-and-tsunami--impact-on-lcds |title=Japan 2011 earthquake and tsunami: impact on LCDs |first=Isaac |last=Leung |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011 |publisher=Electronics News}}</ref> The [[iPad]], which companies began developing games for soon after its release,<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/5890/game_strategies_ipad_vs_iphone.php| title = Game Strategies: iPad vs. iPhone| publisher=Gamasutra| first = Paul| last = Hyman| date = 8 July 2010| accessdate =21 March 2011}}</ref> was expected to be available in short supply due to components that are manufactured in Japan.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12782566| title = Japan disaster: Supply shortages 'in three months'|publisher=BBC | date = 18 March 2011| accessdate =21 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="Edge-iPad2">{{cite web| url = http://www.next-gen.biz/news/uk-ipad-2-launch-facing-delay| title = UK iPad 2 Launch Facing Delay| publisher = Edge| first = Nathan| last = Brown| date = 18 March 2011| accessdate = 21 March 2011| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110321065032/http://www.next-gen.biz/news/uk-ipad-2-launch-facing-delay| archivedate = 21 March 2011| df = dmy-all}}</ref> Apple indefinitely delayed the Japanese release of the [[iPad 2]].<ref name="Edge-iPad2"/> Due to production disruptions, Sony announced that it may decide to limit the initial release of [[PlayStation Vita]] to one [[regional lockout|region]] by the end of 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Edwards |first=Clifford |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-04/sony-new-playstation-portable-may-be-delayed-by-japan-disaster.html |title=Sony PlayStation Portable Holiday Release May Be Delayed by Japan Disaster |publisher=Bloomberg |date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=6 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/130847/20110405/sony-ngp-playstation-portable-delayed.htm |title=Sony's NGP Delayed By Japan Disaster |work=International Business Times |publisher=Ibtimes.com |accessdate=6 April 2011}}</ref> Investment research company Zachs described the situation as uncertain, adding that if there is a radiation leak at [[Fukushima Prefecture|Fukushima]]'s nuclear plants, it could shut down operations all over Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zacks.com/stock/news/49069/Video+Games+Up,+Japan+Casts+Shadow |title=Video Games Up, Japan Casts Shadow |publisher=Zacks.com |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Yakuza PS3 2011 Teaser.jpg|thumb|Early screesnhot of ''Ryū ga Gotoku Of the End'', depicting a city in ruin. It was erroneously believed to portray an "earthquake or other natural disaster".<ref name="gibiz"/>]]
The disaster's effects on Japan has affected a number of planned releases. Jesse Divnich, an analyst for [[EEDAR]], expected video game delays to be the biggest impact of the disaster on the video game industry, asserting this as being due to the inflexibility of development schedules.<ref name="msnbc">{{cite web |last=Benedetti |first=Winda |url=http://ingame.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2011/03/15/6273963-video-game-industry-hit-by-disaster-in-japan |title=In-Game – Video game industry hit by disaster in Japan |publisher=msnbc |accessdate=16 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130104050240/http://ingame.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2011/03/15/6273963-video-game-industry-hit-by-disaster-in-japan |archivedate=4 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Kevin Gifford of [[1UP.com]] noted that the country's "strained" distribution networks and the number of consumers focused on the events of the disaster would result in losses should a video game be released.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.1up.com/news/japan-review-check-doa-dimensions| title = Japan Review Check: DOA Dimensions, FFIV Complete| publisher = 1UP.com| first = Kevin| last = Gifford| date = 17 March 2011| accessdate = 21 March 2011| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111104091937/http://www.1up.com/news/japan-review-check-doa-dimensions| archivedate = 4 November 2011| df = dmy-all}}</ref> Some games, due to their subject matter being perceived as too similar to the real-life events, have had their releases delayed indefinitely, including [[Sony Computer Entertainment]]'s ''[[MotorStorm: Apocalypse]]''.<ref name="shacknews"/> While it has entered distribution channels in the United Kingdom, Sony announced that they will cease any further shipments and remove marketing material for it.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hoggins |first=Tom |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/video-games/8383384/UK-release-of-Motorstorm-Apocalypse-delayed-in-light-of-Japan-tsunami.html |title=UK release of Motorstorm Apocalypse delayed in light of Japan tsunami |publisher=Telegraph |date= 15 March 2011|accessdate=16 March 2011 |location=London}}</ref> [[Sega]] similarly delayed their video game, ''[[Yakuza: Dead Souls|Ryū ga Gotoku Of the End]]'', indefinitely.<ref name="shacknews">{{cite web|url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/67815/video-game-industry-feels-earthquakes |title=Video game industry feels Earthquake's effect |publisher=Shacknews |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> Early in ''Ryū ga Gotoku Of the End''{{'}}s unveiling, it was mistakenly thought to depict an "earthquake or other natural disaster."<ref name="gibiz">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2011-03-14-japanese-stocks-hit-in-market-slump |title=Japanese market slumps as publishers react to tragedy , News |publisher=Gamesindustry |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> [[Irem]]'s upcoming release of ''[[Zettai Zetsumei Toshi 4: Summer Memories]]'' and ''[[Poncotsu Roman Daikatsugeki Bumpy Trot 2]]'' has been cancelled altogether (with the former being re-announced in 2015 with a different title, developer and platform), with the publisher issuing an apology; the game would have been the fourth in a series of survival action games where players would need to escape a city after the onset of a major disaster, specifically a large earthquake in ''Zettai Zetsumei Toshi 4''.<ref name="shacknews"/> Pre-release orders reportedly rose after the disaster.<ref name=autogenerated5>{{cite news|author=Patrick Hoge |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2011/03/15/zynga-japan-earthquake-children.html |title=Zynga players send $1.35M to Japan |publisher=Bizjournals |date= 15 March 2011|accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref>
There have been delays of video games that are not related to earthquakes or disasters; [[Nintendo]] delayed the release of their [[Nintendo 3DS]] video game ''[[Steel Diver]]'' in Japan from its original release date of 17 March, ''[[Major League Baseball 2K11]]'' and ''[[Top Spin 4]]'' were both delayed from their intended release date of April, and ''[[Toaru Kagaku no Railgun]]'' for the [[PlayStation Portable]].<ref name="vg247">{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2011/03/14/japan-quake-charity-begins-local-games-activity-hit-hard/ |title=Japan quake: Sony delays Motorstorm Apocalypse in UK |publisher=VG247 |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> The delay of ''Steel Diver'' is in spite of a statement by Nintendo that it would not postpone the release of any games.<ref name="msnbc"/> [[Konami]] delayed their [[Nintendo DS]] video game ''[[Powerful Golf]]'',<ref name="msnbc"/> [[Microsoft]] delayed the release of ''[[Dragon Age Origins: Awakening]]'' due to "distribution disruption",<ref name="shacknews"/> [[Capcom]] delayed the first download content pack for ''[[Marvel vs. Capcom 3: Fate of Two Worlds]]'' in Japan<ref name="gamespy">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespy.com/articles/115/1155359p1.html |title=Japanese Gaming Companies Step Up in Tohoku Earthquake and Tsunami Relief Efforts – Page 1 |publisher=GameSpy |first=Mike |last=Sharkey |date=14 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317042110/http://www.gamespy.com/articles/115/1155359p1.html |archivedate=17 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and [[Ubisoft]] similarly delayed download content for ''[[Assassin's Creed Brotherhood]]'' in Japan.<ref name="msnbc"/>
Some companies took steps to conserve energy by shutting down servers used for Internet gaming. [[Square Enix]] shut down its servers for ''[[Final Fantasy XI]]'' and ''[[Final Fantasy XIV (2010 video game)|Final Fantasy XIV]]'', while [[Konami]] suspended the servers for ''[[Metal Gear Online]]'' indefinitely.<ref name="shacknews"/> The two ''Final Fantasy'' games along with the [[PlayOnline]] service accounted for 11 percent of Square Enix's energy consumption the previous month. After implementing other energy consumption efforts to reduce energy usage by over 10 percent, including lighting reduction and ceasing office climate control, the company planned to restart the services on 25 March.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/23/ffxiv_and_ffxi_service_restart/| title = Final Fantasy XI, XIV Restart on Friday| publisher = Andriasang| date = 23 March 2011| first = Anoop| last = Gantayat| accessdate = 23 March 2011| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110326212834/http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/23/ffxiv_and_ffxi_service_restart/| archivedate = 26 March 2011| df = dmy-all}}</ref> [[Nintendo]] shut down service for [[Pokémon Global Link]], a feature that was part of the newest additions to the franchise.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} Due to this shutdown, the release date of the feature for other countries has been delayed. [[Hitachi]], one of Nintendo's suppliers for the manufacture of its [[Nintendo DS]] handheld system, has indicated that deliveries of its materials may be delayed, depending on whether its factories are shut down for a period of time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/2012676/quake_disrupts_chip_and_memory_prices/ |title=Quake Disrupts Chip And Memory Prices |publisher=redOrbit |date=22 November 2010 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> Sony announced that while [[PlayStation Network]] services for the [[PlayStation 3]] and PlayStation Portable would not be interrupted, users may experience connection problems, and some content updates will be delayed.<ref name="vg247"/> Sony later urged PSN users to back up their data.<ref name="msnbc"/> [[Microsoft]] delayed the launch of some of their [[Xbox 360]]'s [[Xbox Live]] features that they had planned to release in the week following the disaster.<ref name="msnbc"/> In Japan, Sony temporarily closed their call centers, while it and Microsoft both closed their repair centers.<ref name="msnbc"/>
A number of gaming-related events were canceled in the wake of the disaster. These include a number of demos for video games such as ''[[BlazBlue: Continuum Shift II]]'', ''[[Dragon Ball Zenkai Battle Royal]]'', and others. An event planned to be held for the release of ''Ryū ga Gotoku Of the End'' to allow fans to have their copies signed in [[Hiroshima, Japan|Hiroshima]] and [[Osaka, Japan|Osaka]] was also canceled. A ''[[Monster Hunter]]'' themed event called "''Monster Hunter'' Festa" was also cancelled.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/12/event_cancellations/ |title=Monster Hunter Festa, Other Events Cancelled (andriasang.com, 03.12.2011) |publisher=Andriasang |date=12 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110315083844/http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/12/event_cancellations/ |archivedate=15 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Microsoft]] delayed a tour to advertise its [[Kinect]] controller.<ref name="shacknews"/> The video game tournament [[Evolution Championship Series|Evolution]] vs Godsgarden was canceled over logistic concerns related to the disaster's impact.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/22/evolution_vs_godsgarden_cancel/| title = Evolution vs Godsgarden Fighting Tournament Cancelled| publisher = Andriasang| date = 22 March 2011| first = Anoop| last = Gantayat| accessdate = 23 March 2011| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110325095016/http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/22/evolution_vs_godsgarden_cancel/| archivedate = 25 March 2011| df = dmy-all}}</ref>
==Donations and assistance== {{further|Humanitarian response to the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami}}
===Japanese response===
Several Japanese video game publishers donated relief to Japan; this includes Nintendo, which donated 300 million yen; Sony, which donated 300 million yen and 30,000 radios; [[Sega Sammy]], which donated 200 million yen, and [[Namco Bandai]], Capcom, and [[Tecmo Koei]], which donated 100 million each.<ref name="gamespy"/><ref>{{cite web| first = Jason| last = Schreier| url = https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2011/03/street-fighter-japan-donation/| title = Capcom, Zynga Donate Game Profits to Japan Aid | publisher=Wired| date = 4 January 2009| accessdate =16 March 2011}}</ref> [[CyberConnect2]] opened its offices and offered aid to 30 people from the general public.<ref name="IGN-Quake"/> Sega promised to donate all proceeds earned from ''[[Football Manager 2011]]'' and its ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (series)|Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' titles available for [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]] platforms for a week, beginning on 15 March 2011.<ref name="1up"/> [[Capcom]] lowered the price of the [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]] version of ''[[Street Fighter IV]]'' from $4.99 to $0.99, donating the proceeds of its sales from that point on to tsunami relief.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://kotaku.com/#!5782051/capcom-donating-iphone-street-fighter-iv-sales-to-quake-relief| title = Capcom Donating iPhone Street Fightet IV Sales to Quake Relief| publisher=Kotaku| date = 15 March 2011| accessdate =23 March 2011}}</ref> iOS developer [[5pb.]] slashed the prices of its games from ¥2200 to ¥350 and donating all proceeds to the Red Cross until 31 March.<ref>{{cite web|author=Fred Dutton |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2011-03-14-japan-publishers-donate-to-tsunami-effort |title=Japan publishers donate to tsunami effort News – Page 1 |publisher=Eurogamer.net |date=14 March 2011 |accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref> [[Arc System Works]] employee [[Toshimichi Mori]] commented that he was in talks with his company on making download content to donate some of the proceeds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/14/quake_relief/|title=Publishers Donate to Earthquake Relief|publisher=Andriasang|first=Anoop|last=Gantayat|date=14 March 2011|accessdate=19 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317084832/http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/14/quake_relief/|archivedate=17 March 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Nippon Ichi]] announced that the earnings from the download content release of a character in ''[[Disgaea 4]]'' for ¥100 under the name "Fans of ''Disgaea 4''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/18/disgaea_4_dlc_charity/|title=Disgaea 4 Download Content Revenue Being Donated to Charity|publisher=Andriasang|first=Anoop|last=Gantayat|date=18 March 2011|accessdate=19 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110322003409/http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2011/03/18/disgaea_4_dlc_charity/|archivedate=22 March 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Square Enix]] pledged to donate ¥100 million, as well as giving gamers with Square Enix accounts to use points called "Square Enix Crysta" to donate. They also set up a "worldwide employee charity fund".<ref name="asang">{{cite web |url=http://www.andriasang.com/e/posts/2011/03/17/270072/ |title=Square Enix Donates to Quake Relief |publisher=Andriasang |first=Anoop |last=Gantayat |date=17 March 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110318175911/http://www.andriasang.com/e/posts/2011/03/17/270072/ |archivedate=18 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Level-5 (video game company)|Level-5]] donated 10 million yen, as well as pledging to release charity items through its video game ''[[Inazuma Eleven Mobile]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.andriasang.com/e/posts/2011/03/16/270040/ |title=Level-5 and Inazuma Eleven Support Quake Relief Efforts |publisher=Andriasang |first=Anoop |last=Gantayat |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===International response=== Online gaming publications have launched relief drives of their own. [[IGN]] started up a fundraiser, wherein its staff plays 24 Japanese-made games in 24 hours in an attempt to garner donations of $24,000,<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://psp.ign.com/articles/115/1155629p1.html |title=IGN Japanese Tsunami Relief Fundraiser – PSP Feature at IGN |publisher=IGN |date=14 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> while Brian Crecente of [[Kotaku]] will host the Japan Earthquake Relief Fundraiser on 24 March 2011 in Denver, Colorado, in which proceeds will go to the Japanese Red Cross Society.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://kotaku.com/#!5783264/silent-auction-live-dj-added-to-japan-earthquake-relief-fundraiser/gallery/1| title = Silent Auction, Live DJ Added to Japan Earthquake Relief Fundraiser| publisher=Kotaku| date = 18 March 2011| accessdate =23 March 2011}}</ref> ''[[Game Informer]]''{{'}}s Meagan Marie put up for auction her ''[[Mario (franchise)|Mario]]''-themed [[Nintendo DS]] autographed by several people with links to Nintendo, including [[Shigeru Miyamoto]], [[Koji Kondo]], [[Eiji Aonuma]], [[Charles Martinet]], and [[Video Game Pianist|Martin Leung]], with the proceeds to go to Japanese relief.<ref name=autogenerated6>{{cite web|first = Meagan| last = Marie| url=http://www.gameinformer.com/blogs/editors/b/gimeagan_blog/archive/2011/03/14/auction-to-aid-japan-functional-ds-signed-by-nintendo-luminaries.aspx |title=Auction To Aid Japan: Functional DS Signed By Nintendo Luminaries! |publisher=GameInformer |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> Siliconera put up for auction an action figure of the fictional character [[Cecil Harvey (Final Fantasy)|Cecil]] from ''[[Dissidia: Final Fantasy]]'', signed by ''[[Final Fantasy IV]]'' designer [[Takashi Tokita]].<ref>{{cite web| author=Spencer| url = http://www.siliconera.com/2011/03/14/siliconera-fund-for-the-japan-earthquake-and-tsunami-relief-raffle/| title = Fund For The Japan Earthquake And Tsunami Relief Raffle| publisher=Siliconera| date=14 March 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> The industry's online auction efforts organized into Play For Japan, which acts as an online hub for auctions of collectible video game paraphernalia.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/33664/Play_For_Japan_Organizes_Industry_Auctions_For_Japanese_Relief_Charities.php| title = 'Play For Japan' Organizes Industry Auctions For Japanese Relief Charities| publisher=Gamasutra| first = Kyle| last = Orland| date = 23 March 2011| accessdate =24 March 2011}}</ref>
Non-Japanese video game companies also provided assistance. [[Mastiff (company)|Mastiff]], in addition to a sum of money already donated, pledged to donate $100 for every 100 Facebook likes their page receives, up to $25,000 worth.<ref name="1up">{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/news/ways-gamers-aid-japanese-earthquake-victims |title=More Ways for Gamers to Aid Japanese Earthquake Victims |publisher=1UP |first=Chris |last=Pereira |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629042427/http://www.1up.com/news/ways-gamers-aid-japanese-earthquake-victims |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Shawnimals]] discounted two video games, ''[[Wee Ninja]]'' and ''[[Wee Devil]]'', to $10, pledging to donate all profits made to the relief fund.<ref name="1up"/> ''[[EVE Online]]'' players are able to donate the game's in-game currency, which will be converted into real-world money and given to the Red Cross,<ref>{{cite web|author=John Funk | date=4 March 2011 |url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/108462-Publishers-Developers-and-Gamers-Respond-to-Japanese-Disaster |title=The Escapist : News : Publishers, Developers and Gamers Respond to Japanese Disaster |publisher=Escapistmagazine |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> and players of select Facebook games by [[Zynga]], such as ''[[FarmVille]]'' and ''[[CityVille]]'', can purchase special in-game items, whose profits would go to helping support the Japanese relief effort.<ref>{{cite web |author=Ryan Winterhalter |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/pc/farmville/news/zynga-supporting-relief-efforts-in-japan/a-20110315134315478009/g-20100909111915102029 |title=Zynga supporting relief efforts in Japan, FarmVille PC News |publisher=GamesRadar |accessdate=16 March 2011 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> 36 hours in, Zynga has collected approximately $1.35 million.<ref name=autogenerated5 /> [[ScrewAttack]] announced that all profits made from their game, ''Texting of the Bread'', would go to the [[American Red Cross]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://screwattack.com/videos/Hard-News-031511 |title=Hard News 15 March 2011 , ScrewAttack – Something Original... Every Freakin' Day |publisher=ScrewAttack |accessdate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110318020956/http://screwattack.com/videos/Hard-News-031511 |archivedate=18 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[NEXON Corporation]] announced that all profits made from specific in-game items for sale in their games, such as ''[[MapleStory]]'', will go to the relief effort.<ref name="1up"/> American developer and publisher [[PopCap Games]], in partnership with the Red Cross, discounted its entire line of iOS games and pledged to donate all proceeds to relief efforts.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://kotaku.com/#!5783269/popcap-discounts-all-ios-games-donates-sales-to-japan-earthquake-relief| title = PopCap Discounts All iOS Games, Donates Sales to Japan Earthquake Relief| first = Brian| last = Crecente| publisher=Kotaku| date = 18 March 2011| accessdate =23 March 2011}}</ref> Valve Software announced that they will be donating all proceeds from the purchase of certain items purchased in their game ''[[Team Fortress 2]]''.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.teamfortress.com/post.php?id=5170&p=1| title = If We Could Be Serious For a Moment...| publisher=Valve Corporation| date = 23 March 2011| accessdate =24 March 2011}}</ref> Publisher [[Aksys Games]] initiated a charity sales drive<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.aksysgames.com/2011/03/16/japan-benefit-sale| title = Japan Benefit Sale| publisher=Aksys Games| date = 16 March 2011| accessdate =28 March 2011}}</ref> where all gross proceeds from sales from their website would be donated to Red Cross, raising $34,162.33.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.aksysgames.com/2011/03/25/japan-benefit-sale-draws-to-a-close| title = Japan Benefit Sale Draws to a Close| publisher=Aksys Games| date = 25 March 2011| accessdate =28 March 2011}}</ref> [[NCsoft]] pledged to donate ¥500 million (approx €4.5 million/£3.9 million/$6.3 million), which they describe as "one month's earnings". They also pledged to provide "payment support" to quake victims who cannot log in for "extended periods".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.andriasang.com/e/posts/2011/03/17/270076/ |title=NC Japan Gives One Month Profits to Quake Relief |publisher=Andriasang |first=Anoop |last=Gantayat |date=17 March 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110321011337/http://www.andriasang.com/e/posts/2011/03/17/270076/ |archivedate=21 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.cityofheroes.com/news/news_archive/ncsoft_sends_its_most_heart-fe.html| title=NCsoft sends its most heart-felt condolences to the victims and people of Japan| publisher=NCsoft| date=18 March 2011| accessdate=21 April 2011| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110322143004/http://www.cityofheroes.com/news/news_archive/ncsoft_sends_its_most_heart-fe.html| archivedate=22 March 2011| df=dmy-all}}</ref> Riot Games created charity skins for their League of Legends games that people could purchase, with all proceeds being donated to the Red Cross for Earthquake relief.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leagueoflegends.com/news/nurse-akali-aids-red-cross-wake-japanese-tsunami |title=Nurse Akali Aids the Red Cross in the Wake of Japanese Tsunami | LoL |publisher=League of Legends |date=21 March 2011 |accessdate=18 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628154916/http://www.leagueoflegends.com/news/nurse-akali-aids-red-cross-wake-japanese-tsunami |archivedate=28 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111122170053/http://www.1up.com/features/how-japans-earthquake-changed-developers How Japan's Earthquake Changed its Developers] at 1UP.com
{{2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami}}

{{No footnotes|date=May 2014}} [[File:J.C. Greive - Internationale koloniale tentoonstelling.jpg|{{largethumb}}|The exhibition terrain behind the [[Rijksmuseum Amsterdam|Rijksmuseum]], now [[Museumplein]] square]] [[File:Wereldtentoonstelling 1883. Terrein van de Internationale, Koloniale en Uitvoerhandel Tentoonstelling met links het Koloniaal Gebouw.jpg|{{largethumb}}|The Dutch colonial pavilion, with a statue of [[Jan Pieterszoon Coen]] ]] [[File:Wintertuin krasnapolsky.jpg|{{largethumb}}|To profit from the event, [[Hotel Krasnapolsky]] was expanded with 125 rooms and the ''Wintertuin'', shown here]]
The '''International Colonial and Export Exhibition''' (Dutch: ''Internationale Koloniale en Uitvoerhandel Tentoonstelling''; French: ''Exposition Universelle Coloniale et d'Exportation Générale'') was a [[colonial exhibition]] (a type of [[World's Fair]]) that was held in [[Amsterdam]] from May 1 to October 1, 1883. The event drew at least a million visitors and was the first international colonial exhibition, with 28 different nations presenting their colonial trade and wealth.
The event was the brainchild of [[Edouard Agostini]], a French entrepreneur. Agostini, who had previously been involved in organizing the 1878 [[Exposition Universelle (1878)|Exposition Universelle]] in Paris, presented his plans to the city of Amsterdam and King [[William III of the Netherlands]] in 1880. The Dutch government was initially hesitant, but Agostini managed to secure funding from Belgian and French investors.
The location chosen for the exhibition was an unused area of land behind the [[Rijksmuseum Amsterdam|Rijksmuseum]], which at that time was still under construction. This area is now [[Museumplein]] square. The main building was designed by the French architect [[Paul Fouquiau]] in "[[Moorish Revival architecture|Moorish]]" style. It was constructed of wood covered with plaster and painted cloth, in order to give the impression of marble. Between the building's two large towers, a large cloth in "Indian" style was hung, with plaster heads of elephants and other animals. The building contained pavilions representing 28 different nations, including [[France]], [[German Empire|Germany]], the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]], [[Belgium]], [[Japan]], the [[United States]], [[China]], [[Canada]], the [[Ottoman Empire]], [[Thailand|Siam]] (Thailand), [[South African Republic|Transvaal]], and the host country, the [[Netherlands]].
Items on show in the main building included a telephone, wood- and metalworking machines, and a safe large enough to fit eight people. The building's colonial section presented products such as tobacco and rubber, as well as a reconstructed [[Java]]nese-style settlement (''kampung'') with "natives". At that time, it was not considered degrading or racist to put humans on display; in fact, it became a regularly featured spectacle at such exhibitions (see further: [[Human zoo]]).
Other structures included a music pavilion; the pavilion of the city of Amsterdam; the Dutch colonial pavilion; a Japanese bazar; various shops; and Dutch, English and German restaurants. In front of the Dutch colonial pavilion was a statue of [[Jan Pieterszoon Coen]] who, as governor-general of the Dutch East Indies, played a large part in the Dutch conquest of the Indonesian archipelago. A canal with a bamboo bridge and a Chinese [[junk (ship)|junk]] intersected the exhibition grounds.
==Effects== The exhibition, bringing more than a million visitors from around the world to Amsterdam, provided the city with a huge economic boost. A number of hotels were expanded or newly built in order to profit from the large number of visitors, including the [[American Hotel, Amsterdam|Hotel Americain]], the {{Interlanguage link multi|Doelen Hotel|nl}}, and [[Hotel Krasnapolsky]]. The expansion of the Krasnapolsky included the glass-roofed ''Wintertuin'' lounge, with [[electric light]]ing, which at that time was considered a real novelty.
In Amsterdam, modern-day remains of the exhibition are the front gate of the [[Vondelpark]] and a collection of items in the [[Tropenmuseum]] which were on show in the Dutch colonial pavilion. Some items from the Dutch colonial pavilion were also donated to the ethnological museum of [[Natura Artis Magistra|Artis]] zoo and, after this museum was closed, ended up in the Tropenmuseum as well. However, the lion's share of the thousands of items from this pavilion was donated to the [[National Museum of Ethnology (Netherlands)|National Museum of Ethnology]] in [[Leiden]]. Some parts of the German restaurant are now in the [[Veenkoloniaal Museum]] in [[Veendam]].
[[Heineken International|Heineken]] still uses the label ''Diplôme d'Honneur'' on its beer bottles, an honour that was bestowed on the brewer at the 1883 colonial exhibition.
==See also== *[[Colonial Exhibition of Semarang]], a 1914 Colonial Exhibition in the Dutch East Indies
==Further reading== *Alberdingk Thijm, J.A., "De waereldtentoonstelling van 1883", in: ''De Gids'' 1883, III, pp. 292-310. (Dutch) *Bloembergen, Marieke, ''De koloniale vertoning; Nederland en Indië op de wereldtentoonstellingen (1880-1931).'' Amsterdam: Wereldbibliotheek, z.j. {{ISBN|90-284-1925-X}} (Dutch)
==External links== {{commonscat|International Colonial Exhibition}} * [http://parallel.park.org/Netherlands/pavilions/world_expositions/map.htm Map showing the layout of the exhibition terrain]
==Sources== * [http://parallel.park.org/Netherlands/pavilions/world_expositions/index_2.htm World Expositions in Amsterdam - 1883] * [http://archief.parool.nl/artikel?text=Atjeh-pilaar&SORT=presence&ED=ola&PRD=3m&SEC=%2A&FDOC=0 "Canon van Amsterdam". ''Het Parool'', 14 April 2008] (Dutch) * [http://www.lib.umd.edu/digital/worldsfairs/essay.jsp?pid=umd:1013 University of Maryland libraries: 1883 Colonial Exposition, Amsterdam]
{{coord|52.357|4.881|type:event_region:NL|display=title}}

[[File:Birth of a nation Aryan quote.jpg|thumb|Intertitle in ''[[The Birth of a Nation]]'' (1915)]] [[File:The_Cabinet_of_Dr._Caligari_intertitle.png|thumb|''[[The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari]]'' (1920) used stylised intertitles.]] [[File:Spirit 43 - Average Donald Duck Title card - títol.JPG|thumb|right|A title card of a ''Donald Duck'' short film; the design is typical of those used in Disney shorts during the studio's partnership with [[RKO Radio Pictures]] (1937–1954).]] In [[film]]s, an '''intertitle''' (also known as a '''title card''') is a piece of filmed, printed text edited into the midst of (i.e. ''inter-'') the photographed action at various points. Intertitles used to convey character dialogue are referred to as "dialogue intertitles", and those used to provide related descriptive/narrative material are referred to as "expository intertitles".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chisholm|first=Brad|title=Reading Intertitles|year=1987|journal=Journal of Popular Film and Television|volume=15|issue=3|page=137|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/01956051.1987.9944095|doi=10.1080/01956051.1987.9944095}}</ref> In modern usage, the terms refer to similar text and logo material inserted at or near the start of films and television shows.
==Silent film era== In this era intertitles were always called "subtitles"<ref>The New Historical Dictionary of the American Film Industry, by Anthony Slide, Routledge (2014), entry on Subtitles.</ref><ref>Definition 4a of 'subtitle' in the Oxford English Definition: "(In) Film, Television, etc.=intertitle. Now chiefly historical."</ref> and often had [[Art Deco]] motifs. They were a mainstay of [[silent film]]s once the films became of sufficient length and detail to necessitate dialogue and/or narration to make sense of the enacted or documented events. ''The British Film Catalogue'' credits the 1898 film ''Our New General Servant'' by [[Robert W. Paul]] as the first British film to use intertitles.<ref>The British Film Catalogue, by Denis Gifford (Routledge, 2016), page 142.</ref> Film scholar Kamilla Elliott identifies another early use of intertitles in the 1901 British film ''[[Scrooge, or, Marley's Ghost]]''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Dickens on Screen|first=Kamilla|last=Elliot|page=117|isbn=978-0521001243|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mpdrgN082GoC&pg=PA117&lpg=PA117&dq=1901+intertitles&source=bl&ots=nraWDTMOAp&sig=bChGp_xDj1VPbJrK5I5PSKi6yIo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=kaeBUPOXBerO0QXMgoDQBA&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=1901%20intertitles&f=false}}</ref> The [[1st Academy Awards|first Academy Awards]] presentation in 1929 included an award for "Best Title Writing" that went to [[Joseph W. Farnham]] for no specific film. The award was never given again, as intertitles went out of common use due to the introduction of "[[Sound film|talkies]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.awardsandshows.com/features/best-title-writing-33.html|title=Best Title Writing|work=Awards and Shows|accessdate=12 November 2012}}</ref>
==Modern use== {{unreferenced section|date=December 2015}} In modern use, intertitles are used to supply an [[Epigraph (literature)|epigraph]], such as a poem, or to distinguish various "[[Act (theatre)|acts]]" of a film or multimedia production by use as a title card. However, they are most commonly used as part of a historical drama's epilogue to explain what happened to the depicted characters and events after the conclusion of the story proper.
The development of the [[soundtrack]] slowly eliminated their utility as a [[Narration|narrative]] device (they were common for providing narration, but not dialogue, well into the 1930s), but they are occasionally still used as an artistic device. For instance, intertitles were used as a [[gimmick]] in ''[[Frasier]]''. The BBC's drama ''[[Threads]]'' uses them to give location, date and information on distant events beyond [[Sheffield]]. ''[[Law & Order]]'' and its related spinoffs used them to give not only the location, but also the date of the upcoming scene. [[Guy Maddin]] is a modern filmmaker known for recreating the style of older films, and uses intertitles appropriately. Some locally produced shows, such as [[quiz bowl]] [[game shows]], use animated variations of intertitles to introduce the next round.
==Amateur use== Intertitles have had a long history in the area of [[amateur film]] as well. The efforts of [[Home movies|home movie]] aficionados to intertitle their works post-production have led to the development of a number of innovative approaches to the challenge. Frequently lacking access to high quality film dubbing and splicing equipment, amateur film makers must plan ahead when making a film to allow space for filming an intertitle over the existing film. Intertitles may be printed neatly on a piece of paper, a card, or a piece of cardboard and filmed, or they may be formed from adhesive strips and affixed to glass. In the early 1980s, digital recording technology improved to the point where intertitles could be created in [[born-digital]] format and recorded directly onto the film. Several specialty accessories from this period such as Sony's HVT-2100 Titler and cameras such as Matsushita's Quasar VK-743 and Zenith VC-1800 could be used to generate intertitles for home movies.<ref name=woodcock>{{cite magazine |last= Woodcock |first= Roderick |author-link= Roderick Woodcock|date= May 1983 |title= The TV Den: Understanding Techniques and Technology |magazine= [[Video (magazine)|Video]]|publisher= Reese Communications|volume= 7|issue= 2|pages= 20–21|issn= 0147-8907}}</ref>{{rp|20}} Early 1980s video game consoles and applications catering to the [[demo scene]] were also adapted for the generation and recording of intertitles for home films. Among these were included the [[ColecoVision]], the [[Magnavox Odyssey²]] (using programs such as the ''Type & Talk'' cartridge and the ''Voice'' module), the [[Bally Astrocade]] (using the built-in ''Scribbling'' program or the more advanced ''Creative Crayon'' cartridge), and the intertitle-specialized [[Famicom Titler]].<ref name=woodcock/>{{rp|21}}
==See also== * [[Acknowledgment (creative arts)]] * [[Billing (filmmaking)]] * [[Character generator]] * [[Closing credits]] * [[Credit (creative arts)]] * [[Digital on-screen graphic]] (bug) * [[Lower third]] * [[Opening credits]] * [[Subtitle (captioning)]] * [[Supertitle]] * [[Title sequence]] * [[WGA screenwriting credit system]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{Commons category|Intertitles}}

{{Infobox Chinese-language singer and actor | name = Ivan Heng | gender = male | image = Ivan Heng after a performance of La Cage, Esplanade Theatre, Singapore - 20120729 (cropped).jpg | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = Heng after a [[W!LD RICE]] performance of ''La Cage'' (an adaptation of ''[[La Cage aux Folles (play)|La Cage aux Folles]]'') at the Esplanade Theatre, [[Esplanade – Theatres on the Bay]], Singapore, on 29 July 2012 | background = actor_or_actress | chinesename = | tradchinesename = 王愛仁 | simpchinesename = 王爱仁 | pinyinchinesename = Wáng Àirén | bopomofochinesename = | jyutpingchinesename = | yalechinesename = | pojchinesename = | vietnamesename = | birth_name = | othername = | ethnicity = [[Peranakan]] | origin = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|09|20}} | birth_place = [[Singapore]] | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | residence = [[Singapore]] | education = | alma mater = [[Anglo-Chinese School]]
[[Temasek Junior College]]
[[National University of Singapore]]
[[Royal Conservatoire of Scotland]] | nationality = [[Singaporean]] | occupation = actor, theatre director | years_active = | agent = | genre = | instrument = | voicetype = | label = | agentcompany = | yearsactive = | associatedact = | spouse = {{married|Tony Trickett|2014}} | partner = | children = | parents = Nancy Ong (mother)
| siblings = | relatives = [[Tan Kheng Hua]] | ancestry = | influences = | influenced = | website = {{URL|http://www.wildrice.com.sg/}} | alias = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | currentmembers = | pastmembers = | hongkongfilmwards = | goldenbauhiniaawards = | hkfcsawards = | asianfilmawards = | goldenhorseawards = | huabiaoawards = | goldenroosterawards = | hundredflowersawards = | goldeneagleawards = | flyingapsarasawards = | rthktop10goldsongsawards= | goldenmelodyawards = | mtvasiaawards = | ntsawards = | chinamusicawards = | goldenbellawards = | tvbanniversaryawards = | magnoliaawards = | asiantvawards = | rainbowawards = | awards = [[Cultural Medallion]] (2013) }} '''Ivan Heng''' ({{zh|t=王愛仁|s=|p=Wáng Àirén}};{{cite web|title=Connect the Dots|url=http://eml.uzyn.com/hkfringe/files/pgm_guide_spotlight_singapore.pdf|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060211030640/http://eml.uzyn.com/hkfringe/files/pgm_guide_spotlight_singapore.pdf|archivedate=11 February 2006|publisher=Hong Kong City Festival, [[Hong Kong Fringe Club]]|date=January 2006}} born 20 September 1963) is a [[Singaporean]] actor and theatre director of [[Peranakan]] descent. He is the founding artistic director of [[W!LD RICE]], a theatre company in Singapore, and an outspoken advocate for respect for diversity and freedom of expression. Heng is the first male Singaporean actor to break into English-speaking roles in Hollywood films with his role in [[Luc Besson]]'s ''[[The Fifth Element]]'', the first female actress from Singapore being Lydia Look, who played a Fuzhou actress in a [[Jackie Chan]] Hollywood film. ==Biography== A theatre director, actor, playwright and designer, Heng's productions are concerned with identity, migration and gender and sexual politics within intercultural contexts. They have played festivals and theatres in more than 20 cities around the world including Melbourne International Arts Festival, New Zealand International Arts Festival, Edinburgh Fringe, ICA International Festival of the Chinese Diaspora (London), Hong Kong City Festival, [[Royal Tropical Institute]] (Netherlands), SIETAR Congress (Munich), WOTM Conference (Belgium) and Re:Map Festival (Copenhagen). Heng’s background is in both Asian and Western theatre traditions: training as a director with [[Kuo Pao Kun]] of Practice Performing Arts in Singapore; ballet, jazz and contemporary dance as a scholar with Dance Arts Singapore; and training with the Peking Opera in Hong Kong (Hong Kong Tang's Opera Troupe) and Singapore (Leling Peking Opera Troupe, Chinese Theatre Circle). He also spent a summer at the British American Drama Academy in Oxford. His mentor, colleague and closest collaborator was [[:zh:克里申吉|Krishen Jit]] with whom he collaborated on ''M. Butterfly'', ''The Coffin is too Big for the Hole'', ''No Parking on Odd Days'', ''Emily of Emerald Hill'' and ''The Visit of the [[Tai tai]]''. ===Early years=== Heng was educated at [[Anglo-Chinese School]], [[Temasek Junior College]] and the [[National University of Singapore]], where he studied law from 1984 to 1988. He was admitted to practice as lawyer until the acting bug led him to various theatres, winning many awards in Edinburgh, London, Canada and finally Hollywood.{{cite web|title=Ivan Heng: Biography|url=http://www.artseefartsee.com/ivanheng/bio.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717053818/http://www.artseefartsee.com/ivanheng/bio.html|archivedate=17 July 2012|publisher=Artseefartsee.com|accessdate=17 July 2012}} Heng was awarded the [[Cultural Medallion]], Singapore's highest arts honour, in 2013.{{cite news|author=Mayo Martin|title=Cultural Medallion, Young Artist Award recipients announced|url=http://www.todayonline.com/entertainment/arts/cultural-medallion-young-artist-award-recipients-announced?singlepage=true|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131025011814/http://www.todayonline.com/entertainment/arts/cultural-medallion-young-artist-award-recipients-announced|archivedate=25 October 2013|work=[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]]|date=22 October 2013}} Whilst studying for his law degree, Heng attended Kuo's directing workshop, acted with Singapore Theatre American Repertory Showcase (S*TARS), and directed and designed sets as a founding member of [[The Necessary Stage]]. Heng originated the lead role of Malcolm Png in [[Michael Chiang]]'s ''Army Daze'' in 1987. He also played Frankie Wong in ''Beauty World'', and Song Liling in the All-Asian premiere of ''M. Butterfly'' in India in 1989 (a role originated on the West End by his future collaborator [[Glen Goei]]). Heng also performed in ''M. Butterfly'' at the [[Singapore Arts Festival]] in 1990. ===Overseas work=== In 1990, Heng became the first recipient of the BAT Arts Scholarship to the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama (Glasgow). He graduated with top honours, including the Royal Lyceum Theatre Award for Best Shakespearean Performance (''Richard III''), the Margaret Gordon Award for Best Final Year Performance, and the Dorothy Innes Prize for Best Studentship. Heng made his UK directorial debut at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival with a Singaporean play – Ovidia Yu's ''The Woman in a Tree on the Hill''. The production won the Scotsman Edinburgh Fringe First (Singapore's first and only), as well the ''Scottish Daily Express'' New Names of '93 Award. Thereafter, he moved to London where he worked in film, television and radio, and founded the Tripitaka Theatre Company to do touring productions with an Asian point of view, like his autobiographical solo ''Journey West'' (1995).{{cite news|author=Clarissa Oon|title=On a cultural mission|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/showbiz/cultural-mission|work=[[The Straits Times]] (reproduced on [[AsiaOne]])|date=25 October 2013}} ===Return to Singapore=== In 1998, after touring extensively throughout Europe, Heng decided to return to Singapore to contribute and make a difference to Singapore's nascent arts scene. In 2000, Heng founded W!LD RICE. His projects for the company include directing ''The Campaign to Confer the Public Service Star on JBJ'', ''Second Link – The Singapore Malaysia Text Exchange'', ''Oi! Sleeping Beauty!!'', ''The Visit of the Tai Tai'', ''Landmarks – Asian Boys Vol.2'', ''Cinderel-lah!'', ''Animal Farm'', ''Ang Tau Mui'', ''The Woman in A Tree on the Hill'', ''An Occasional Orchid''; set designing ''The Magic Fundoshi'', ''Boeing Boeing'', ''Landmarks'', ''Ang Tau Mui'', ''Animal Farm'', ''An Occasional Orchid'', and Kuo Pao Kun's ''The Coffin is too Big for the Hole'' and ''No Parking on Odd Days''; and acting in ''The Visit of the Tai Tai'', ''For the Pleasure of Seeing Her Again'', ''Emily of Emerald Hill'', ''Animal Farm'', ''La Cage Aux Folles'' and ''The Importance of Being Earnest''. Other highlights of his career include acting in ''Army Daze'', ''Beauty World'' (both original casts) and ''M. Butterfly'' (India, Canada, Singapore); conceiving and directing ''Ah Kong's Birthday Party'' (Singapore's longest-running play); directing ''Dim Sum Dollies Steaming!'' and ''Singapore's Most Wanted'' (Esplanade Theatre), ''Phua Chu Kang: the Musical'' for the President of Singapore’s Star Charity, Puccini’s ''Madama Butterfly'' for the Singapore Lyric Opera (Esplanade Theatre), and co-directing and performing in ''Hotel Grand Asia'', a three-year intercultural collaboration involving 16 theatre artists from seven cities at the Setagaya Public Theatre in Tokyo. In 2006, Heng was Artistic Director of the inaugural Singapore Theatre Festival, which was presented by W!LD RICE and featured nine productions by five theatre companies, including five World Premieres, seminars and workshops. In 2009, he served as Creative Director for Singapore's [[Singapore National Day Parade|National Day Parade]].[http://www.insing.com/news/celebrities-entertainment/Interview-Leading-the-Parade/id-93120100/?nav=60000]. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} In 2010, he was Creative Director for the Opening and Closing Ceremonies of the inaugural [[Youth Olympic Games]] held in Singapore. Heng's awards for excellence in theatre include the Edinburgh Fringe First, ''Scottish Daily Express'' New Names of '93 Award, Edinburgh Spirit of the Fringe 1995, Singapore Young Artist Award 1996, the Singapore Youth Award 1998, the ''Straits Times Life!'' Theatre Award for Best Director 2002, the Singapore Tatler Leadership Award for Culture (2006) and the Cultural Medallion in 2013. He shares his practice by giving workshops internationally, and has taught at the Central School of Speech and Drama (London), Tramway (Glasgow), Intercult (Stockholm), Kannonhallen (Denmark), Dramalab (Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia), and [[LASALLE College of the Arts]] in Singapore. He was also a participant at London's Royal Court Theatre 10th International Summer Residency. ==Personal life== In August 2014, Heng married his long-time partner Tony Trickett in London. Heng met Trickett, now the executive director of W!LD RICE, in 1996.{{cite news|author=Boon Chan|title=Ivan Heng weds his partner of 18 years on a 'perfect British summer's day'|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/theatre-dance/story/ivan-heng-weds-his-partner-18-years-perfect-british-summers-day-201408|work=The Straits Times|date=3 August 2014|accessdate=5 September 2014}} ==Filmography== ===Films=== *2013: ''Sex.Violence.FamilyValues.'' – Pole Dance Judge *1999: [[Rogue Trader (book)|Rogue Trader]] – Singapore Bartender *1997: [[The Fifth Element]] (Le Cinquième élément) – Left Arm ===Plays=== *2015: ''Public Enemy'' – Dr. Thomas Chee *2013: ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' – Lady Bracknell *2012: ''La Cage Aux Folles'' – Albin *2011: ''Emily of
