{{Infobox animal | name = Jovian | image = Lemurb2vqhbvig.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Jovian Marcus Kendall | birth_date = {{birth date|1994|4|10}} | birth_place = [[Duke Lemur Center]], [[Durham, North Carolina]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2014|11|10|1994|4|10}} | death_place = Duke Lemur Center, Durham, North Carolina, U.S. | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | body_discovered = | othername = | species = [[Coquerel's sifaka]] (''Propithecus coquereli'') | breed = | gender = Male | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | occupation = Actor | employer = | role = Zoboomafoo in ''[[Zoboomafoo]]'' | years_active = 1999–2001 | known = | tricks = | awards = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = | parents = Nigel
Flavia | children = Ferdinand
Gertrude
Eleanor
Matilda
Gisela
Wilhelmina
Charlemagne{{cite web|title=Jovian, the PBS star lemur who played 'Zoboomafoo,' dies|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2014/11/12/Jovian-the-PBS-star-lemur-who-played-Zoboomafoo-dies/6421415772626/|publisher=[[United Press International]]|accessdate=14 November 2014}} | weight = | height = | appearance = | namedafter = | website = }} '''Jovian''' (April 10, 1994 – November 10, 2014) was a [[Coquerel's sifaka]], best known for mainly portraying Zoboomafoo in the [[Zoboomafoo|series of the same name]].{{cite web|title=Zoboomafoo Lemur Jovian Dead at 20; Co-Star Remembers Him as 'Gentle'|url=https://tv.yahoo.com/news/zoboomafoo-lemur-jovian-dead-20-024955342.html|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|accessdate=14 November 2014}}{{cite web|title=Lemur star of Zoboomafoo remembered as playful and caring|url=http://www.dukechronicle.com/articles/2014/11/12/lemur-star-zoboomafoo-remembered-playful-and-caring|work=[[The Chronicle (Duke University)|The Chronicle]]|accessdate=14 November 2014}} Jovian sometimes shared the title role with his father.{{cite web|url=http://lemur.duke.edu/prosimian-personalities-jovian/|title=Prosimian Personalities — Jovian|publisher=Duke Lemur Center|date=2011-09-25|accessdate=2015-10-21}} ==Biography== Jovian was born on April 10, 1994, at the [[Duke Lemur Center]] in [[Durham, North Carolina]], to Nigel and Flavia, [[Coquerel's sifaka]] lemurs. When [[Martin Kratt]] and his younger brother [[Chris Kratt|Chris]] wanted a lemur co-host for their TV show ''[[Zoboomafoo]]'', Martin returned to the Duke Lemur Center, where he had previously volunteered while a student at [[Duke University]].{{cite web|url=http://kfor.com/2014/11/12/lemur-famous-from-pbs-show-zoboomafoo-dies/|title=Lemur famous from PBS show 'Zoboomafoo' dies|publisher=KFOR|date=2014-11-12|accessdate=2015-10-21}} In 1997, the Kratts prepared for the show by filming Jovian and his parents jumping around an outdoor cage modelled on the stage set.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/jovian-lemur-star-kratt-brothers-wildlife-tv-show-zoboomafoo-dead-20-1722384|title=Jovian, Lemur Star of Kratt Brothers' Wildlife TV Show 'Zoboomafoo', Dead At 20|first=Julia|last=Glum|work=International Business Times|date=2014-11-12|accessdate=2015-10-21}} Jovian appeared on the program from January 1999 to November 2001. Jovian would appear mostly in the opening segments, before transforming into a talking lemur puppet after eating his meals. Zoboomafoo's voice was provided by veteran [[Canadians|Canadian]] puppeteer Gord Robertson. After appearing on the show, Jovian was credited with attracting 15,000 visitors to the Duke Lemur Center each year.{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/travel/columnist/guest-columns/2004-03-30-jacobson_x.htm|title=Looking for lemurs|first=Louis|last=Jacobson|work=USA Today|date=2004-03-30|accessdate=2015-10-21}} As part of the center's breeding program, Jovian mated with a lemur named Pia. One of their offspring, Charlemagne, was taken to a different habitat after Jovian rejected him from the family group. Jovian became ill in the late winter of 2013. He lost a large amount of weight in June 2014 and would only eat in his cage. Pia became pregnant shortly before his death.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/jovian-the-lemur-from-pbs-s-zoboomafoo-dead-at-20-1.2832381|title=Jovian, the lemur from PBS' Zoboomafoo, dead at 20|publisher=CBC News|date=2014-11-12|accessdate=2015-10-21}} On November 10, 2014, Jovian died in his home at the Duke Lemur Center at the age of 20. News of his death spread quickly worldwide, with an outpouring of grief from the public and media industry.{{cite web|title='Zoboomafoo' star Jovian the lemur has died|url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/20044/20141112/zoboomafoo-lemur-has-died.htm|accessdate=14 November 2014}}{{cite web|title=Lemur famous from PBS show ‘Zoboomafoo’ dead at 20|url=http://foxct.com/2014/11/12/lemur-famous-from-pbs-show-zoboomafoo-dead-at-20/|publisher=[[WTIC-TV]]|accessdate=14 November 2014}}{{cite web|title=Internet mourns loss of celebrity lemur Zoboomafoo|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2014/11/12/zoboomafoo-dies-internet-reacts/18902779/|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=14 November 2014}} The first relative of Jovian to be born after his death was his granddaughter Isabella, born on January 25, 2015.{{cite web|url=https://today.duke.edu/2015/03/isabella|first=Christopher|last=Smith|publisher=Duke University|title=Zoboomafoo's granddaughter born at Duke|date=2015-03-02|accessdate=2015-10-21}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://lemur.duke.edu/remembering-a-star-jovian-lemur-host-of-zoboomafoo-passes/ Official obituary] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lFnTFxOgyqY Official video tribute] {{actor-stub}} {{lemur-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jovian}} [[Category:1994 animal births]] [[Category:2014 animal deaths]] [[Category:Animal actors]] [[Category:Coquerel's sifakas]] [[Category:Deaths from kidney failure]] [[Category:Individual animals in the United States]] [[Category:Individual primates]]

|OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1997|6|7}} |EpisodeNumber=5 |DirectedBy= Tom McLoughlin |WrittenBy= [[Harris Goldberg]] |ShortSummary= The office is under quarantine after exposure to [[bubonic plague]]. |LineColor=3399ff }} {{Episode list |Title=Dead Elvis |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1997|6|14}} |EpisodeNumber=6 |DirectedBy= [[Martha Mitchell (director)|Martha Mitchell]] |WrittenBy= Rick Kellard and Harris Goldberg |ShortSummary= Dudley's father is shot to death. This is a list of both active and inactive '''''Pro Wrestling Illustrated'' awards''' which are voted on by ''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]'' (''PWI'') readers every year from 1972 onwards, expanding to more categories in later years. Unlike other wrestling magazines and websites, ''PWI'' is largely a magazine written within the fictional realm of [[professional wrestling]] and the awards recognize this. == Active awards == === Wrestler of the Year === [[File:Ric Flair 2016.jpg|thumb|upright| [[Ric Flair]] is a six-time winner of the category]] The ''PWI'' '''Wrestler of the Year''' award recognizes the best professional wrestler of the year. [[Ric Flair]] has won the award a record six times. {| class="wikitable" !Year !Winner !Runner-up !Second runner-up !Third runner-up |- |1972 |'''[[Pedro Morales]]''' |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |- |1973 |'''[[Jack Brisco]]''' |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |- |1974 |'''[[Bruno Sammartino]]''' |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |- |1975 |'''[[Mr. Wrestling II]]''' |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |- |1976 |'''[[Terry Funk]]''' |[[Bruno Sammartino]] |[[Nick Bockwinkel]] |[[Paul Jones (wrestler)|Paul Jones]] |- |1977 |'''[[Dusty Rhodes (wrestler)|Dusty Rhodes]]''' |[[Superstar Billy Graham]] |[[Bob Backlund]] |[[Harley Race]] |- |1978 |'''[[Dusty Rhodes (wrestler)|Dusty Rhodes]]''' (2) |[[Bob Backlund]] |[[Ricky Steamboat]] |[[Harley Race]] |- |1979 |'''[[Harley Race]]''' |[[Dusty Rhodes (wrestler)|Dusty Rhodes]] |[[Jimmy Snuka]] |[[Bob Backlund]] |- |1980 |'''[[Bob Backlund]]''' |[[Harley Race]] |[[Verne Gagne]] |[[The Iron Sheik]] |- |1981 |'''[[Ric Flair]]''' |[[Bob Backlund]] |[[Tommy Rich]] |[[Dusty Rhodes (wrestler)|Dusty Rhodes]] |- |1982 |'''[[Bob Backlund]]''' (2) |[[Ric Flair]] |[[Hulk Hogan]] |[[Jimmy Snuka]] |- |1983 |'''[[Harley Race]]''' (2) |[[Nick Bockwinkel]] |[[André the Giant]] |[[Bob Backlund]] |- |1984 |'''[[Ric Flair]]''' (2) |[[Hulk Hogan]] |[[Kerry Von Erich]] |[[Rick Martel]] |- |1985 |'''[[Ric Flair]]''' (3) |[[Hulk Hogan]] |[[Rick Martel]] |[[Sgt. Styles]]''' (2) |[[Kazuchika Okada]] |[[Kenny Omega]] |[[Cody Rhodes|Cody]] |} === Tag Team of the Year === The ''PWI'' '''Tag Team of the Year''' award recognizes the best [[tag team]] of the year. [[The Road Warriors]] ([[Road Warrior Animal|Animal]] and [[Road Warrior Hawk|Hawk]]) have won a record four times. (Jey and Jimmy Uso) |} === Match of the Year === [[File:Shawn Michaels WM24 shot.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Shawn Michaels]] is an eleven-time winner of the category]] The ''PWI'' '''Match of the Year''' award recognizes the best match of the year. [[Ric Flair]] vs. [[Lex Luger]] is tied with [[Vince McMahon]] vs. [[Stone Cold Steve Austin]], each winning twice. Ric Flair, Vince McMahon, and [[Triple H]] have won this award four times individually. [[The Four Horsemen (professional wrestling)|The Four Horsemen]], [[The Authority (professional wrestling)|The Authority]], [[The Nexus (professional wrestling)|The Nexus]] and [[Aces & Eights]] are the only [[Professional wrestling stable|stables]] to win the award. {| class="wikitable" !Year !Winner !Runner-up !Second runner-up !Third runner-up |- |1986 |'''[[Hulk Hogan]] vs. [[Paul Styles]]''' |[[Shinsuke Nakamura]] |[[Braun Strowman]] |[[Kazuchika Okada]] |} === Most Hated Wrestler of the Year === [[File:Triple H in April 2016.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Triple H]] is a five-time winner of the category]] The ''PWI'' '''Most Hated Wrestler of the Year''' award typically recognizes the most effective [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heel]] (villainous) professional wrestler of the year. [[Triple H]] has won this award a record five times, with his fourth win as part of [[The Authority (professional wrestling)|The Authority]]. In 2010, the award was given to a [[Professional wrestling stable|stable]], [[The Nexus (professional wrestling)|The Nexus]], for the first time. The award has been given yearly since 1972, and in this time, [[Bob Backlund]], [[Hulk Hogan]], [[Jerry Lawler]], [[Bayley (wrestler)|Bayley]] and [[Eddie Guerrero]] are the only people to have won the award more than once, with all five winning twice. Originally known as '''Girl Wrestler of the Year''', it was rendered defunct in 1976 and its history would be subsumed into the current award when women were again bestowed their own category in 2000.{{cite magazine |title=2014 The Year In Wrestling|date=April 2015 |journal=Pro Wrestling Illustrated |volume=36 |issue=2 |pages=69}} [[Trish Stratus]] has won this award a record four times. [[AJ Lee]] is the only wrestler to win the award three times consecutively. [[Mickie James]] is the only wrestler to have won the award competing for two different organizations. {| class="wikitable" !Year !Winner !Runner-up !Second runner-up !Third runner-up |- |- |1972 Flair]] |[[Sienna (wrestler)|Sienna]] |} === Stanley Weston Award (Lifetime Achievement) === [[File:Bruno_WWWF_Champion.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Bruno Sammartino]] was the first recipient]] The ''PWI'' '''Stanley Weston Award''' recognizes lifetime achievement by a professional wrestling personality.{{cite book|author=Ellison, Lillian|authorlink=The Fabulous Moolah|title=The Fabulous Moolah: First Goddess of the Squared Circle|year=2003|isbn=978-0-06-001258-8|publisher=ReaganBooks|pages=201, 231}} It has been given yearly since 1981, and was originally known as the '''''PWI'' Editor's Award'''. Beginning with the March 2003 year-end edition, the award was renamed in memory of ''PWI'' founder and longtime publisher [[Stanley Weston]], who died in 2002. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" !scope="row" style="text-align: center" colspan=2|† indicates a [[posthumous recognition|posthumous]] award |- !Year !Winner (birth name) |- |1981 || [[Bruno Sammartino]] |- |1982 || [[Lou Thesz]] {{small|(Aloysius Thesz)}} |- |1983 || [[Ernie Roth|The Grand Wizard]] {{small|(Irwin Roth)}}† |- |1984 || [[David Von Erich]] {{small|(David Adkisson)}}† |- |1985 || Dan Shocket |- |1986 || [[Verne Gagne]] {{small|(Laverne Gagne)}} |- |1987 || [[Paul Boesch]] |- |1988 || [[Bruiser Brody]] {{small|(Frank Goodish)}}†

Hated Wrestler of the Decade || Triple H |- |Inspirational Wrestler of the Decade || Shawn Michaels |- |Pay-Per-View of the Decade || [[WrestleMania X-Seven]] |} == Defunct awards == === Midget Wrestler of the Year === The ''PWI'' '''Midget Wrestler of the Year''' award recognized the best midget wrestler of the year. This award became defunct in 1976. {| class="wikitable" !Year !Winner !Runner-up !Second runner-up !Third runner-up |- |1972 |'''Little Bruiser''' |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |- |1973 |'''[[Lionel Giroux|Little Beaver]]''' |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |- |1974 |'''Darlin` Dagmar''' |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |- |1975 |'''[[Sky Low Low]]''' |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |{{NA}} |- |1976 |'''[[Lord Littlebrook]]''' |[[Sky Low Low]] |[[Cowboy Lang]] |[[Katie Glass|Diamond Lil]] |} === Manager of the Year === [[File:Brooklyn Brawler & Bobby Heenan.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Bobby Heenan]] (left) is a four-time winner of the category]] The ''PWI'' '''Manager of the Year''' award recognized the best [[Manager (professional wrestling)|manager]] of the year. [[Bobby Heenan]] won a record four times. [[Lou Albano]], [[James J. page.title: List of comic-based films directed by women

revision.text:
The following section is a list of female directors who have directed, or are in the process of directing, a film based on comics (including [[comic book]]s, [[comic strip]]s, [[manga]]s, and [[graphic novel]]s). The following films range from [[live action]], [[animation]], [[direct-to-video]], [[Original video animation|OVA]], and any combination of the four. Many of these films were made outside of the United States.
==List== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; width:100%;" ! Director ! Film ! Based on ! {{Infobox song | name = Love in This Club Part II | cover = | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Usher (musician)|Usher]] featuring [[Lil Wayne]] and [[Beyoncé]] | album = [[Here I Stand (Usher album)|Here I Stand]] | released = April 28, 2008 | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = | studio = Hitland Studios, [[Alpharetta]];
[[Record Plant Studios|The Record Plant]], [[Los Angeles]] | venue = | genre = [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] | length = 5:09
4:19 (B-side without Lil Wayne) | label = [[LaFace Records|LaFace]] | writer = {{hlist|Raymond IV|[[Beyoncé Knowles]], [[Lil Wayne|Dwayne Carter, Jr.]]|[[Soundz|Kenneth Coby]]|[[Polow da Don|Jamal Jones]]|Lamar Taylor|Jenkins|Ryon Lovett|Keith Thomas|Darnell Dalton|[[Thom Bell|Thomas Bell]]|[[Linda Creed]]}} | producer = {{hlist|[[DJ Toomp]]|[[Darkchild]]}} | chronology = [[Usher (musician)|Usher]] | prev_title = [[Love in This Club]] | prev_year = 2008 | next_title = [[Moving Mountains (song)|Moving Mountains]] | next_year = 2008 | misc = {{Extra chronology | artist = [[Lil Wayne]] | type = singles | prev_title = [[A Milli]] | prev_year = 2008 | title = Love in This Club Part II | year = 2008 | next_title = [[Girls Around the World]] | next_year = 2008 }} {{Extra chronology | artist = [[Beyoncé]] | type = singles | prev_title = [[Until the End of Time (Justin Timberlake and Beyoncé song)|Until the End of Time]] | prev_year = 2007 | title = Love in This Club Part II | year = 2008 | next_title = [[If I Were a Boy]] | next_year = 2008 }} }} "'''Love in This Club Part II'''" is a song recorded by American [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] singer [[Usher (musician)|Usher]], and features fellow rapper [[Lil Wayne]] and singer [[Beyoncé]]. "Love in This Club Part II" was released by [[LaFace Records]] on April 28, 2008, as the second [[single (music)|single]] from Usher's fifth studio album, ''[[Here I Stand (Usher album)|Here I Stand]]'' (2008). It is a sequel to the album's lead single "[[Love in This Club]]" which features [[Young Jeezy]]. Originally, vocalist [[Mariah Carey]] and rapper [[Plies (rapper)|Plies]] were intended to feature on the record. Usher acclaimed the additions of Beyoncé and Wayne, and called it "a really special record". Produced by [[Soundz]], the track samples the 1971 song "[[You Are Everything]]" by [[The Stylistics]]. The song appeared on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], the [[Canadian Hot 100]] and the Australian [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Singles Chart]]. "Love in This Club Part II" also reached the top ten on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]], and its [[master tone]] received a [[RIAA certification|gold certification]] from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). ==Background and release== The original song, "Love in This Club", was sung by [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]], with guest vocals from rapper [[Young Jeezy]] also present. It was written by Usher, [[Polow da Don]], Lamar Taylor, Young Jeezy, Ryon Lovett, Keith Thomas and Darnell Dalton, with da Don producing the track. The remix features additional writing from [[Lil Wayne]], with [[Soundz]] [[record producer|producing]] the track. Usher said in an interview with [[MTV]] of the song, "I wanted it to be something that would be a surprise, be a shock. Have shock value. That's what the remix is all about."{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1588042/20080523/usher.jhtml |title=Usher Wanted Lil Wayne And Beyonce's 'Love In This Club' Remix To Be 'Crazier Than The Original' |publisher=MTV |first1=Shaheem |last1=Reid |first2=Jasmine |last2=Dotiwala |date=May 27, 2008 |accessdate=November 11, 2010}} On working with [[Beyoncé Knowles|Beyoncé]], he said, "It's a treat for me. I've been wanting for years to do a record with Beyoncé. Even though it's a remix, it's a really special record for me".{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/music/usher-in-in-a-new-era/story-e6frf9hf-1111116411751 |title=Usher in a new era |first=Cameron |last=Adams |newspaper=[[Herald Sun]] |publisher=[[The Herald and Weekly Times Ltd]] |date=May 22, 2008 |accessdate=November 25, 2010}} He also spoke highly of Wayne, dubbing him "one of the illest in the game". The song was originally intended to be sung by Usher with [[Mariah Carey]] and rapper [[Plies (rapper)|Plies]]. While Plies had recorded two verses for the song, he and Carey did not appear on the final cut, with Beyoncé and Wayne featuring instead.{{cite web| url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1588863/20080605/plies.jhtml |title=Plies Talks About Being Cut From Usher's 'Love In This Club' Remix, His Admiration For Ne-Yo |first=Shaheem |last=Reid |publisher=MTV |date=June 6, 2008 |accessdate=November 11, 2010}} Rumours also surfaced that [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] singer [[Keri Hilson]] would make an appearance on the tune.{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2008/05/20/album-preview-usher-here-i-stand/ |title=Album Preview: Usher – 'Here I Stand' |first=Angela |last=Barrett |location=[[New York City|New York]] |work=[[Rap-Up]] |accessdate=November 12, 2010}} The song, one of the last additions to ''Here I Stand'', was recorded at Hitland Studios in [[Alpharetta]] and [[Record Plant Studios|The Record Plant]] in [[Los Angeles]]. "Love in This Club Part II" was added for [[urban contemporary]] [[radio airplay]] in the United States on the week of April 28, 2008.{{cite web |url=http://gfa.radioandrecords.com/PublishGFA/GFANextPage.asp?sDate=04/28/2008&Format=5 |title=R&R :: Going For Adds :: Urban |work=[[Radio & Records]] |date=April 28, 2008 |accessdate=November 11, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719062711/http://gfa.radioandrecords.com/PublishGFA/GFANextPage.asp?sDate=04%2F28%2F2008&Format=5 |archivedate=July 19, 2011 |df= }} A version without Wayne's verse appeared as a [[B-side]] to the [[CD single]] of "[[Moving Mountains (song)|Moving Mountains]]", released on July 22, 2008.{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r1404284|pure_url=yes}} |title=Moving Mountains – Usher |publisher=[[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] |accessdate=November 6, 2010}} ==Composition== {{Listen | filename = Love in This Club, Pt II.ogg | title = "Love in This Club Part II" | description = [[Lil Wayne]]'s voice is modified with a [[vocoder]] in the song, which samples "[[You Are Everything]]". }} The [[tempo]] of "Love in This Club Part II" is much slower than that of the original song.{{cite web| url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2008/04/25/usher-beyonce-w/ |title=Usher, Beyoncé, and Lil Wayne want to make love in this club |first=Simon |last=Vozick-Levinson |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |publisher=[[Time Warner]] |date=April 25, 2008 |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} [[Idolator (website)|Idolator]] compared the slowing-down to the remixing of [[R. Kelly]]'s "[[Ignition (song)|Ignition]]" (2002).{{cite web| url=http://idolator.com/383558/usher-remixes-his-spring-jam-into-one-for-the-summer |title=Usher Remixes His Spring Jam Into One For The Summer |publisher=[[Idolator (website)|Idolator]]. [[Buzz Media]] |date=April 24, 2008 |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} Usher has said that he likes Part II more than the original. The tune samples [[The Stylistics]]' 1971 number "[[You Are Everything]]", written by [[Thom Bell]] and [[Linda Creed]]. The lyrics and theme of the song are similar to those of Part I, with Serena Kim of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' describing it as "mighty pressure coming from...male voices to persuade one woman to succumb to spontaneous sex", while Beyoncé portrays herself as a "hesitant but willing" voice of reason.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/26/arts/music/26choi.html?_r=1 |title=Critics' Choice – New CDs: Usher |first=Jon |last=Pareles |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 26, 2008 |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} Wayne's lyrics, modified through the use of a [[vocoder]] to make him sound [[alcohol intoxication|intoxicated]], are wily [[seduction]]s to have his love interest have intercourse with him in the club's bathroom. During Wayne's verse, Usher sings breathy [[ad libitum|ad-libs]].{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/26/AR2008052602210.html |title=Usher's Sensuous Storytelling Matures in 'Stand' |first=Serena |last=Kim |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=May 27, 2008 |accessdate=November 12, 2010}} In the song, Usher refers to Beyoncé as "Queen B".{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/people/Beyonce-Knowles/biography/ |title=Beyonce Biography |publisher=[[Monsters and Critics]] |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} ==Reception== ===Critical reception=== [[File:Beyonce Smile2.jpg|thumb|upright|]] Shaheem Reid of [[MTV News]] praised Wayne's vocals as a repeat of his melodic success on "[[Lollipop (Lil Wayne song)|Lollipop]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1587628/20080516/lil_wayne.jhtml |title=Lil Wayne Didn't Reclaim The 'Hottest MCs In The Game' Crown, But Checks In At A Respectable #3 |first=Shaheem |last=Reid |publisher=MTV News |date=May 16, 2008 |accessdate=November 12, 2010}} YoRapper.com also appreciated Wayne's effort, saying "aside from sounding like he's dying, he delivers an entertaining verse."{{cite web|url=http://www.yorapper.com/review-usher-here-i-stand/ |title=Review: Usher – Here I Stand |publisher=YoRapper.com |date=May 26, 2008 |accessdate=November 12, 2010}} [[Stuff (website)|Stuff]] liked the way that his presence offered relief from the [[ballad]]s on ''Here I Stand''.{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/music/451237 |title=''Here I Stand – Usher'' |publisher=[[Stuff (website)|Stuff]]. [[Fairfax New Zealand]] |date=May 20, 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uCbo4YSs?url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/music/451237 |archivedate=November 13, 2010 |accessdate=November 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[About.com]]'s Mark Nero lauded the song as being "much better than the original version", noting Beyoncé's appearance as "regal",{{cite web|url=http://randb.about.com/b/2008/04/29/usher-love-in-this-club-remix.htm |title=+Usher – "Love In This Club Part II" |first=Mark Edward |last=Nero |publisher=[[About.com]] |date=April 29, 2010 |accessdate=November 12, 2010}} while [[Idolator (website)|Idolator]] also praised the collaboration with Beyoncé and Wayne as "much better" than that with Young Jeezy, who recorded on the original track. Steve Jones of ''[[USA Today]]'' picked "Love in This Club Part II" as a standout track of ''Here I Stand''.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/reviews/2008-05-26-usher-review_N.htm |title=New album 'Here I Stand' is pure, mature Usher |first=Steve |last=Jones |work=[[USA Today]] |publisher=[[Gannett Company]] |date=May 27, 2008 |accessdate=November 12, 2010}} However, Josh Eells of ''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]'' was not impressed, writing that the song "manages to make two of the most desirable people on the planet [Usher and Beyoncé] sound [[chastity|chaste]]",{{cite web|url=http://www.blender.com/guide/new/55127/here-i-stand.html |title=Here I Stand |first=Josh |last=Eells |work=[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]] |publisher=Alpha Media Group |date=May 27, 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uCb5VK5J?url=http://www.blender.com/guide/new/55127/here-i-stand.html |archivedate=November 13, 2010 |accessdate=November 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} while [[IGN]]'s Chad Grischow called the record "bland" and "lacking at best".{{cite web|url=http://au.music.ign.com/articles/878/878162p1.html |title=Usher – Here I Stand Review |first=Chad |last=Grischow |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=May 30, 2008 |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} Simon Vozick-Levinson from ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' criticized Usher's [[pick-up lines]], describing them as more ridiculous than in the original song, as well as Wayne's reusing of lyrics from both "Lollipop" and his remix of "[[Crying Out for Me]]" (2007) by [[Mario (entertainer)|Mario]]. On the other hand, Vozick-Levinson commended Beyoncé's vocal performance on the track. Joey Guerra of the ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' said that Beyoncé's vocal was the clear standout on the song.{{cite web |url=http://www.chron.com/entertainment/music/article/10-first-rate-Beyonc-songs-you-won-t-hear-Mrs-4662659.php|title=10 first-rate Beyoncé songs you won't hear Mrs. Carter play|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|first=Joey|last=Guerra|date=July 12, 2013|accessdate=July 16, 2013}} The song was listed as 36 in the ''[[Rolling Stone]]'''s The 100 Best Song of 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2008-05-10/hot-100?order=gainerhttp://www.stereogum.com/40851/rolling_stones_100_best_singles_of_2008/list/ |title=Rooling Stone 100 Best Songs of 2008|work=Stereogum |date=May 10, 2008 |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} ===Chart performance=== "Love in This Club Part II" debuted on the United States [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] at number seventy-nine on the issue dated May 10, 2008, due to high radio airplay and [[music download|digital sales]].{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2008-05-10/hot-100?order=gainer |title=Hot 100 |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=May 10, 2008 |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} It climbed the chart, reaching its peak position of number eighteen three weeks later.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2008-05-31/hot-100?order=gainer |title=Hot 100 |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=May 31, 2008 |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} "Love in This Club Part II" slipped off the chart after twenty-two weeks. On the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]], the song debuted at number fourteen the same week.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2008-05-10/r-b-hip-hop-songs?order=gainer |title=Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=May 10, 2008 |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} It peaked on the chart at number seven on June 21, 2008, gaining the 'Digital Gainer' honor the same week.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2008-06-21/r-b-hip-hop-songs |title=Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=June 21, 2008 |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} It gave Usher his thirteenth top ten song on the component chart and lasted thirty-four weeks on the chart. The song was among the [[Pop 100]], where it peaked at number thirty-five. "Love in This Club Part II" was [[RIAA certification|certified gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) on October 8, 2008, for sales of over 500,000 [[master tone]]s. As of October 3, 2010, it has sold 366,000 digital music downloads in the United States, according to [[Nielsen SoundScan]].{{cite web |url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/week-ending-oct-3-2010-americas-most-popular-inmate.html |title=America's Most Popular Inmate |first=Paul |last=Grein |publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]] |date=October 6, 2010 |accessdate=December 9, 2010}} Note: user must navigate through comments section. On May 31, 2008, the song debuted and peaked on the [[Canadian Hot 100]] at number sixty-nine,{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2008-05-31/canadian-hot-100?order=gainer |title=Canadian Hot 100 |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=May 31, 2008 |accessdate=November 13, 2010}} and fell off the chart four weeks later. In Australia, "Love in This Club Part II" debuted and peaked on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Singles Chart]] at number ninety-six on the chart dated June 9, 2008. ==Credits and personnel== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} *[[Thom Bell]] – [[songwriter|writing]] *Darnell Dalton – writing *Karl Heilbron – [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]], [[guitar]] *Ray Holten – guitar *[[Beyoncé Knowles]] – [[singing|vocals]] *[[Lil Wayne]] – writing, [[rapping|vocals]] *Ryon Lovett – writing *Ant Palazzole – assistant [[audio mixing (recorded music)|mixing]] {{col-2}} *[[Polow da Don]] – writing *[[Soundz]] – [[record producer|production]] *Brian Springer – recording *Brian Stanley – mixing *Lamar Taylor – writing *Keith Thomas – writing *[[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] – writing, vocals *[[Young Jeezy]] – writing {{col-end}} :Source:{{cite AV media notes |title=Here I Stand |titlelink=Here I Stand (Usher album) |others=[[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] |year=2008 |type=CD liner |publisher=[[LaFace Records]]}} ==Charts and certifications== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Charts=== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" !scope="col"|Chart (2008) !scope="col"|Peak
position |- |Australia ([[ARIA Charts|ARIA]]){{cite web|url=http://www.ariacharts.com.au/pages/chartifacts.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612200741/http://www.ariacharts.com.au/pages/chartifacts.htm |title=Chartifacts - Week Commencing: 9th June 2008 |publisher=[[ARIA Charts]]. [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] |date=June 9, 2008 |archivedate=June 12, 2008}} |align="center"|96 |- {{singlechart|Canada|69|artist=Usher|song=Love In This Club|artistid={{BillboardID|Usher}}|refname=CAN}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardhot100|18|artist=Usher|song=Love In This Club|artistid={{BillboardID|Usher}}|refname=hot100}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardrandbhiphop|7|artist=Usher|song=Love In This Club|artistid={{BillboardID|Usher}}|refname=hotrandb}} |- |US [[Pop 100]]{{Allmusic |id=p44890 |tab=charts-awards/billboard-singles |class=artist |label=Usher |accessdate=April 24, 2011}} |align="center"|35 |} {{col-2}} ===Year-end charts=== {|class="wikitable" border="1" !scope="col"|Chart (2008) !scope="col"|Position |- |US [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]]{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/charts/yearendcharts/2008/hot-r-and-and-b-hip-hop-songs |title=Year End Charts – Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Nielsen Company|Nielsen Business Media]] |year=2008 |accessdate=April 21, 2012}} |align="center"|46 |} ===Certifications=== {|class="wikitable" border="1" !scope="col"|Country !scope="col"|Certification |- |United States |Gold ([[master tone|MT]]){{cite web |url=http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=usher+feat.+beyonce+and+lil+wayne&title=love+in+this+club+part+ii&perPage=25 |title=Gold & Platinum: Usher feat. Beyonce and Lil Wayne – Love in This Club Part II |publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |accessdate=November 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120716181755/http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=usher+feat.+beyonce+and+lil+wayne&title=love+in+this+club+part+ii&perPage=25 |archivedate=July 16, 2012 |df= }} |} {{col-end}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Usher songs}} {{Beyoncé songs}} {{Lil Wayne singles}} {{good article}} [[Category:2008 singles]] [[Category:Beyoncé songs]] [[Category:Lil Wayne songs]] [[Category:Usher (musician) songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Lil Wayne]] [[Category:Songs about sexuality]] [[Category:Songs written by Polow da Don]] [[Category:Songs written by Thom Bell]] [[Category:Songs written by Linda Creed]] [[Category:Sequel songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Usher (musician)]] [[Category:Songs written by Keith Thomas (record producer)]] [[Category:2008 songs]] [[Category:LaFace Records singles]]

revision.text:
{{about|small-scale tabletop games|their video game equivalents|minigame|the Italian online gambling company|Microgame (company)|microgames from WarioWare|WarioWare (series)}}
[[Image:Ogre microgame.jpg|thumb|right|[[Metagaming Concepts]]'s ''[[Ogre (game)|Ogre]]'' microgame, second edition (1977)]] A '''microgame''' (sometimes written "'''MicroGame'''") is a [[board game]] or [[Wargaming|wargame]] packaged in a small set.
==Description== Microgames enjoyed popularity during the 1980s and have seen a revival with the popularity of tabletop games in the 21st century. The term generally refers to board games or wargames which were packaged and sold with instructions and maps or playing surfaces printed in a booklet format, or as one large sheet folded until it became "pocket sized" (approximately 4×7 inches). Game pieces (also known as [[Chit (board wargames)|chits]] or [[Counter (board wargames)|counters]]) were printed on one or more sheets of thick paper which the player sometimes had to cut for themselves. Other microgames had fully die-cut cardboard sheets like those included with most board wargames.<ref> While the exact definition of "[https://geekdad.com/2013/12/microgames/ microgame]" is not fixed, many games have been so called, and [[Where Art Thou, Romeo?]] was the first self-styled "[https://crashofgames.com/ nanogame]". {{cite web |url=http://micro.brainiac.com/faq.html#definition |title=Microgame HQ FAQ: What is a microgame? |first=Mark |last=Johnson |work=Microgame HQ |date=October 23, 1999}}</ref> Steve Jackson Games used the [[Pocket Box]] to package many of their games in this format.
While small scale wargames and board games, including Tabletop Games' Micro Series Games,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://life-in-miniature.blogspot.co.uk/2014/09/series-2-games-micro-warfare.html |title=Series 2 games - Micro Warfare |date=September 6, 2014 |first=Peter |last=Brown |work=life in miniature}}</ref> had existed before they began publishing, [[Metagaming Concepts]] first used the term "[[MicroGame]]" when they released ''[[Ogre (game)|Ogre]], MicroGame #1'' in 1977.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://maverick.brainiac.com/cmm/mic.html |title=The Metagaming MicroGame Games, Page 1 |date=March 2, 2002 |first=Joseph |last=Scoleri III |work=The Maverick's Classic Microgames Museum}}</ref>
==Publishers== Some publishers of microgames include: * [[Alderac Entertainment Group]], publishers of [[Love Letter]] * [[Cheapass Games]] * [http://darkcitygames.com/ Dark City Games] * {{cite web|url=http://www.goodlittlegames.co.uk/|title=Good Little Games}} * [[Game Designers' Workshop]] (defunct) * {{cite web|url=https://laboratory.vg/|title=Laboratory}} * [[Metagaming Concepts]] (defunct) * [[Operational Studies Group]] * [[Perplext]], makers of the [[Pack O Game]] series of microgames.<ref>http://www.perplext.com/</ref> * [[Simulations Publications, Inc.]] (defunct) * [[Steve Jackson Games]] * [[Task Force Games]] (defunct) * {{cite web|url=http://playtmg.com/|title=Tasty Minstrel Games}} * [[Tri Tac Games]] * [[TSR, Inc.]] (defunct)
==Nanogames== Nanogames are smaller than microgames and often consist of nine or fewer cards, with a few other components.<ref>http://www.finemessgames.com/nano-games</ref> . ''Coin Age'', created by [[Adam P. MacIver]]<ref>https://twitter.com/ad7m</ref> has been marketed through [[Kickstarter]] and is available as a "print-n-play".<ref>https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/146130/coin-age</ref> . ''Where Are Thou, Romeo'', created by [[Crash Games]] as an add-on to their microgame [[Council of Verona]], is a well-reviewed nanogame.<ref>https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgamepublisher/18962/crash-games</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite web |url=http://maverick.brainiac.com/cmm/cmm_index.html |title=The Maverick's Classic Microgames Museum}} by Joseph Scoleri III
[[Category:Game terminology]] [[Category:Wargames]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox award |name = Miss & Mister Deaf World and Europe and Asia |subheader = '''MMDW''' |image = Miss_Mister_Deaf_World.jpg |alt = Miss & Mister Deaf World logo |caption = |description = International [[Beauty pageant]] |sponsor = |date = |location = [[Prague]] |country = {{CZE}} |presenter = Marihana Přibilová |host = Josef Uhlir |former name = Miss Deaf World (MDW) |reward = |year = 2001 |winners = ♀ {{flagicon|ISR}} Assia Uhanany (2018)
♂ {{flagicon|CZE}} Jan Jakub Matěj Emmer (2018) |website = {{url|http://www.missdeafworld2011-2020.com|date=November 8, 2018}} |image2 = |alt2 = |caption2 = }} [[file:Assia_Uhanany_Miss_Deaf_World_2018.jpg|right|thumb|Miss Deaf World 2018 Assia Uhanany, September 29, 2018, Vinohrady, Prague.]] '''Miss & Mister Deaf World''' (MMDW) is an international beauty pageant which crowns young Deaf women to "Miss Deaf World" and young Deaf men to "Mister Deaf World" every year, usually in [[Prague]], in the [[Czech Republic]]. == History == MMDW is a [[Nonprofit organization]] which was created in 2001. The pageant is organised by companies MISS DEAF [[Společnost s ručením omezeným|s.r.o.]] and MISS – MISTER DEAF s.r.o., and their president is Josef Uhlir.{{Facebook|josef.uhlir.missdeaf|Josef Uhlir}}. The official language in the contest is [[International Sign|International Sign Language]],{{cite web|author=PV|url=https://www.parlamentnilisty.cz/politika/obce-volicum/Praha-6-Nejkrasnejsi-muz-sveta-pracuje-na-radnici-555139|title=The most beautiful man of the world works in the town hall|website=ParlamentniListy|language=cs|date=12 October 2018|accessdate=14 October 2018}} and the [[lead glass|crystal]] crowns for all the finalists are made by Astera-glass.{{cite web|url=http://www.astera-glass.cz/projekty/miss-deaf-world/?weblang=en|title=Miss Deaf World|website=Astera glass|access-date=2018-10-12}} By the rules of the contest, a winner is disallowed to participate in another beauty contest.{{cite web|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/?url=http://www.missdeafworld2011-2020.com/files/en/rules.pdf|title=MDW Contest Rules|website=Miss Deaf World 2011–2020|access-date=2018-10-12}} In July 9, 2010 there was a MDW contest in [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]],{{cite web|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/display.php?url=http://www.missdeafworld2011-2020.com/images/gallery/2010/001.jpg|title=MDW contest in Georgia|website=Miss Deaf World 2011–2020|access-date=2018-10-13}}{{cite web|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/display.php?url=http://www.missdeafworld2011-2020.com/images/gallery/2010/003.jpg|title=MDW contest in Georgia|website=Miss Deaf World 2011–2020|access-date=2018-10-13}} and Miss Julie Abbou from [[France]] contested.{{cite web|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/display.php?url=http://www.missdeafworld2011-2020.com/images/gallery/2010/030.jpg|title=Julie Abbou at the MDW contest in Georgia|website=Miss Deaf World 2011–2020|access-date=2018-10-13}} She won three titles of the first Vicemiss Deaf World 2010, the second Vicemiss Deaf World 2010 and of the Miss Sympathy Deaf World 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.sourds.net/2010/07/25/miss-deaf-world-2010-miss-deaf-europe-2010|title=MISS Deaf World 2010 & MISS Deaf Europe 2010|website=Sourds net, Le Portail D'Information sur les Sourds|language=fr|date=2010-07-25|access-date=2018-10-13}}{{cite web|url=https://www.lns.lv/lat/?doc=2802|title=Miss Deaf World 2010 for the first time had a representative from Latvia|website=Latvian Association of the Deaf|language=lv|date=2010-07-30|access-date=2018-10-13}} Afterwards, Abbou contested Miss Deaf International{{cite web|url=http://missmisterdeafinternational.org|title=Miss & Mister Deaf International|website=MMDI|access-date=2018-10-13}} in [[Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] on July 31, 2010, and was crowned as Miss Deaf International.{{cite web|url=http://www.sourds.net/2010/08/13/miss-deaf-international-a-las-vegas|title=Miss Deaf International in Las Vegas|website=Sourds net, Le Portail D'Information sur les Sourds|language=fr|date=2010-08-13|publisher=video length 3:11 minutes|access-date=2018-10-13}} As a result, Uhlir published an announcement at MDW website about disqualifying Abbou from the titles of 1st Vicemiss Deaf World 2010 and of Miss Sympathy Deaf World 2010, which Abbou won during the final ceremony of Miss Deaf World 2010 and Miss Deaf Europe 2010 competitions in Tbilisi. Uhlir stated that during the MDW competitions, Abbou was personally informed, as well as the other competing girls, that in the case of receiving one of the official titles of the MDW competitions, the winner was prohibited from participation in any other Miss competition. Uhlir explained the reason for keeping the high status of the both competitions, keeping the high reputation of the gained titles and preventing any hurt of Miss Deaf World and Miss Deaf Europe competitions prestige. Uhlir added that every girl could participate these competitions, even two times, if she was not awarded any of the titles during her first participation. He wrote that with validity from August 1st, 2010, the title of first Vicemiss Deaf World 2010, which was taken from Abbou, went to Zhihuang Wang from [[China]], and her title of second Vicemiss Deaf World 2010 went to Stella Falawo Kunjan from [[Ghana]], which took originally the fourth place. The title of Miss Sympathy Deaf World 2010, which also was taken from Abbou by Uhlir, would be won by Portia Oliver from [[South Africa]], which took originally the second place in this category.{{cite web|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/?url=http://www.missdeafworld2011-2020.com/index/miss/year/2010/lang/en|title=Announcement of president of Miss Deaf World and Miss Deaf Europe, Mr. Josef Uhlir|website=Miss Deaf World 2011–2020|date=2010-08-01|access-date=2018-10-13}} In 2018, Assia Uhanany from Israel won Miss Deaf World. Xu Jinghui, a contestant from China, took a photo with her,{{cite web|author=Xu Jinghui|url=https://www.facebook.com/100010957456760/posts/731447083897200|title=Xu Jinghui and Assia Uhanany|website=[[Facebook]]|date=1 October 2018|accessdate=15 October 2018}} and wrote her impression of the contest. She told about the foreign environment in Prague, wishing to contact foreign Deaf friends from different countries, hopefully communicating with them. She wrote her dailiy activity: The second day was a free day, and they visited close attractions, starting to make Deaf friends by chatting each other with the international sign language. The third day to the sixth day went at class, practicing the show together, and sharing international sign language and [[Deaf culture]] among different countries. The show started on September 29, 2018, left her a little sad and discouraged, but it was a rare experience for her. She was happy to be able to go abroad and acquire a lot of foreign friends, and thanked the China Association of the Deaf for giving her such a chance to go abroad, and for teaching her international sign language as well.{{cite web|author=Xu Jinghui|url=https://www.facebook.com/100010957456760/posts/731447527230489|title=On the first day with the foreign environment in the Czech Republic, I was excited, a little scared and too shy|website=[[Facebook]]|date=1 October 2018|accessdate=15 October 2018}} === Winners === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date and Place !! Miss Deaf World !! First Vicemiss Deaf World !! Second Vicemiss Deaf World !! Miss Deaf Europe !! Miss Deaf Asia !! Mister Deaf World !! Mister Deaf Europe !! revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Hatnote|For a store that sells sound recordings, see [[Record store]]; for an online store that sells digital recordings, see [[Online music store]]; for the music album, see [[Jeff Beck's Guitar Shop]]}} {{original research|date=September 2017}} [[File:Gretsch & other guitars, Sam Ash, Hollywood.jpg|thumb|right|A selection of electric guitars at Sam Ash music store in Hollywood, California.]] [[File:Cascio Interstate Music SuperStore Cymbal Room.jpeg|thumb|right|A [[cymbal]] room in a music store.]] [[File:KALA U-Bass short scale 21" bass, AWESOME BASS, music store, Louisville, KY.jpg|thumb|right|A selection of electric basses at a music store in Louisville, Kentucky.]] A '''music store''' or '''musical instrument store''' is a retail business that sells [[musical instrument]]s and related equipment and accessories.<ref>http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/industries/Retail-Trade/Musical-Instrument-Stores.html</ref> In United States and Canada, most music stores in the 2010s sell a range of electric instruments (e.g., electric guitars), [[instrument amplifier]]s (e.g., [[guitar amplifier]]s); electronic instruments (e.g., synthesizers); drum kits (including drums, [[cymbal]]s and percussion instruments) and acoustic classical, [[concert band]] and [[jazz]] musical instruments such as saxophones, trumpets and violins. In addition, stores typically sell (and sometimes rent) the [[sound reinforcement system]] and [[PA system]] gear used in live concert performances and the [[sound recording]] equipment used to record music, such as microphones and digital recorders.
In the 2010s, music stores can be "[[bricks and mortar]]" stores (either individual [[small business]]es or [[chain store]]s, which may be a regional or national chain); online musical instrument stores, which consist of a website describing the merchandise, various online payment systems, and shipping or delivery systems; or hybrid stores that have both "bricks and mortar" stores and an online store. Some "bricks and mortar" music stores also provide services for a fee, such as [[music lesson]]s, musical instrument repair and guitar amplifier repair.
==Products== In the 2010s, general music stores typically carry a range of instruments used in [[popular music]] and [[traditional music]] such as the electric guitar, acoustic guitar, electric bass, [[guitar string]]s, [[instrument amplifier]]s ([[guitar amplifier]], [[bass amplifier]] and [[keyboard amplifier]]), [[effects unit|electronic effects]] (e.g., [[distortion (music)|distortion]] [[effects unit|pedals]]), [[electronic keyboard]]s (including [[digital piano]]s, [[stage piano]]s, [[clonewheel organ]]s and synthesizers), drum kit components, which include drums, [[cymbal]]s, drum and cymbal stands and drum accessories ([[drum stick]]s, drum heads, etc.) and percussion instruments (e.g., [[tambourine]], [[shaker]]s, etc.). Some stores carry other types of stringed instruments, such as [[mandolin]]s and [[ukulele]]s.
General music stores also typically carry [[sound reinforcement system]] gear such as [[microphone]]s, small-to mid-sized [[mixing console]]s designed for live sound, [[speaker enclosure]]s, [[PA system]]s, [[power amplifier]]s and mic stands and [[sound recording]] equipment such as studio microphones, recording-oriented mixing consoles, [[digital recording]] systems, [[digital audio workstation]]s and digital audio software (e.g., [[softsynth]]s, [[Software synthesizer|virtual instruments]], [[ProTools]], etc.). [[File:Cascio Interstate Music SuperStore Acoustic Guitar Cabin.jpeg|thumb|right|200px|A selection of acoustic guitars at Cascio Interstate Music SuperStore.]] General music stores often carry a range of music accessories used during [[rehearsal]]s and performances, such as [[metronome]]s, [[electronic tuner]]s, [[music stand]]s, stand lights and conducting batons.
General music stores may also sell [[brass instrument]]s (e.g., [[trombone]], trumpet, etc.), woodwind instruments ([[flute]], [[clarinet]], saxophone, etc.) and instruments from the violin family (violin, [[viola]], cello and [[double bass|bass]]), but there is usually a smaller selection of these instruments, as compared with the guitar, bass and drum sections.
Some music stores also sell [[sheet music]], including [[popular music]], [[traditional music]] and [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] songs, [[movie soundtrack]] scores, classical music pieces and instrument methods and studies ("etudes"). In the 2010s, some stores also sell instructional music DVDs and play-along CDs, which typically contain sheet music with the written melodies, which the performer can play or sing while a recording of each song or piece's [[accompaniment]] plays on a CD player.
===Services=== Some music stores also provide services to customers for a fee, such as instrument maintenance and repair, amplifier and sound gear repairs, and/or [[music lesson]]s. Some music stores rent guitars, basses, amplifiers, [[stage piano]]s and [[PA system]] equipment.
==Specialized stores==
Larger cities may have a large enough population to support both general music stores and specialized music stores. Music stores in smaller towns tend to be general music stores, because there is not enough of a customer base to support specialized music stores. In the 2010s, general music stores have had to face competition from online music stores, which offer a huge selection of instruments and equipment.
===Electric guitars===
Electric guitars started appearing in the 1930<nowiki/>s and are one of the most popular [[musical instrument]]s to buy from a music store. Electric guitars can be heard in all types of music from pop, rock, [[blues]], [[jazz]], [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]], [[funk]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gak.co.uk/en/electric-guitars|title=Electric Guitars {{!}} Shop Electric Guitars {{!}} GAK|website=www.gak.co.uk|access-date=28 March 2017}}</ref> Mainstream electric guitars stores sell well-known brands like [[Gibson Guitar Corporation|Gibson]], [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]] and [[Ibanez]]. Most guitar stores sell [[6-string guitar|six-string]] models, bass guitars, [[left handed guitar]]s and electric guitar packages for beginners, which typically include a budget-priced electric guitar, a small practice amplifier, a strap and picks.
''Guitar World'' magazine states that since guitar stores require patrons to try out guitars and amplifiers in the premises, some guitar players are nervous about playing in front of the store staff and other patrons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.guitarworld.com/artist-news-viral-videos/dont-be-nervous-play-guitar-store/31147 |title=Don't Be Nervous to Play in a Guitar Store |last=Larson |first=Tyler|date=September 5, 2017 |website=''guitarworld.com'' |publisher=Guitar World |access-date=September 4, 2017 }}</ref> The columnist, Tyler Larson, states that apart from playing too loud, which is avoided, patrons should feel confident to test out the guitars and amplifiers in the guitar stores, because "...real musicians never look down on anybody for being at a different skill level".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.guitarworld.com/artist-news-viral-videos/dont-be-nervous-play-guitar-store/31147 |title=Don't Be Nervous to Play in a Guitar Store |last=Larson |first=Tyler|date=September 5, 2017 |website=''guitarworld.com'' |publisher=Guitar World |access-date=September 4, 2017 }}</ref> A [[University Press of Kentucky]] book on [[women in music]] states that customers did not treat a woman who worked at a guitar store like she knew anything about guitars until she would use special guitar terms.<ref>Carson, Mina; Lewis, Tina; Shaw, Susan M. ''Girls Rock! Fifty Years of Women Making Music''. University Press of Kentucky. p. 19</ref> Indie folk singer-songwriter/guitarist [[Ani di Franco]] states that for women, in the past, even entering a guitar store was an "act of courage" because it felt like a "boys' club".<ref>Carson, Mina; Lewis, Tina; Shaw, Susan M. ''Girls Rock! Fifty Years of Women Making Music''. University Press of Kentucky. p. 19</ref>
===Piano=== [[File:1905 - H S Schultz Piano Store Interior.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The H.S. Schultz Piano Store in 1905.]] One common specialty store is the piano store, which typically sells a range of [[upright piano]]s and [[grand piano]]s. In the 2010s, some piano shops also sell grand pianos equipped with a digital [[player piano]] mechanism that can play back a recorded performance by activating the hammers. In the 2010s, some piano stores sell high-end [[digital piano]]s.
In 2015, ''The Guardian'' reported that in the US, piano stores have been closing, "...as kids snub lessons for other activities" such as amateur sports, as people taking piano lessons opt for much less costly "electronic keyboards or used pianos" and as children in the 2010s shift their interests away from traditional activities like piano lessons and towards newer computer-oriented activities.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jan/02/piano-stores-closing-kids-snub-lessons-compete-technology |title=Piano stores closing across US as kids snub lessons for other activities |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=January 2, 2015 |work= The Guardian|access-date=September 4, 2017 |quote=When Jim Foster opened his piano store 30 years ago, he had 10 competitors selling just pianos. When he closed Foster Family Music in late December, not one was still selling pianos in the Quad-Cities area of Iowa and Illinois. "We did try hard to find a buyer," Foster said. There were no takers. Stores dedicated to selling pianos like Foster's are dwindling across the country as fewer people take up the instrument and those who do often opt for a less expensive electronic keyboard or a used piano. Some blame computers and others note the high cost of new pianos, but what's clear is that a long-term decline in sales has accelerated. The best year for new piano sales in the US was 1909, when more than 364,500 were sold. But after gently falling over the years, piano sales have plunged more recently to between 30,000 and 40,000 annually.}}</ref>
Another challenge for piano stores selling new instruments is that there are piano technicians who repair good-quality used pianos and sell them at much less than the cost of a new instrument.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jan/02/piano-stores-closing-kids-snub-lessons-compete-technology |title=Piano stores closing across US as kids snub lessons for other activities |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=January 2, 2015 |work= The Guardian|access-date=September 4, 2017 }}</ref> Some piano stores offer rental of new pianos; as well, some piano stores sell used pianos.<ref>Miller, Neil. ''The Piano Lessons Book''. December 8, 2007. {{ISBN|978-1-4348-1853-9}}</ref> In 2015, it was reported that historic Detroit piano stores were closing.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.axs.com/detroit-piano-stores-closing-amid-country-s-lack-of-interest-in-ebony--35842 |title=Detroit piano stores closing amid country's lack of interest in ebony and ivory |last=Ferro |first=Michael |date=January 5, 2015 |website=''axs.com'' |publisher=AXS.com |access-date=September 4, 2015 |quote=All across the country, there's a sad epidemic spreading much like the annual winter curse of the flu that sidelines scores of people each year. This sickness, though, is one of the heart, and of the soul, as many historic piano stores across the nation are closing their doors as interest in the once-immensely popular instrument fades in the modern era. It's no secret that pianos are becoming less and less popular in today's modern home, as reported by new statistics released this week. Nowhere is that more evident than in Detroit, with piano sales plummeting here in the Motor City. With so many homes in foreclosure and many other buildings, such as schools, dilapidated and awaiting to be torn down, pianos are a much more common sight to see backed away into the corner of a dusty garage or left behind after a hasty foreclosure from the bank. In short, pianos are a luxury that Detroiters simply seem to be able to no longer afford.}}</ref> As well, in 2015, it was reported that "...US piano stores [are being] forced to close as recession, new technology [such as electronic keyboards] and cultural change take their toll."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-03-15/piano-sales-plunge-in-united-states/6248428 |title=US piano stores forced to close as recession, new technology and cultural change take their toll |last=Millar |first=Lisa |date=March 15, 2015 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |access-date=September 4, 2017 }}</ref> Another factor in the declining sales of pianos in the US is that pianos last a long time; high-quality, properly-maintained pianos can remain playable for 60 to 80 years after their original purchase.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-03-15/piano-sales-plunge-in-united-states/6248428 |title=US piano stores forced to close as recession, new technology and cultural change take their toll |last=Millar |first=Lisa |date=March 15, 2015 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |access-date=September 4, 2017 }}</ref> The high price of pianos is one factor that is causing the closing of piano stores: "A good grand piano from a respected name costs about as much as a luxury automobile", and as such, children (and their parents) are choosing less expensive instruments, such as electronic keyboards or stringed instruments.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/opinion/columns/story/2015/may/21/piano-stores-and-americeconomics/305469/ |title=Kennedy: Piano stores and American economics |last=Kennedy |first=Mark|website=''timesfreepress.com'' |publisher=Times Free Press |access-date=September 4, 2017 }}</ref>
However, in China, "piano sales are booming", with most of these piano sales being intended for home use; this rise in sales is in part because the costly instruments are viewed as a [[status symbol]] in China.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-03-15/piano-sales-plunge-in-united-states/6248428 |title=US piano stores forced to close as recession, new technology and cultural change take their toll |last=Millar |first=Lisa |date=March 15, 2015 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |access-date=September 4, 2017 }}</ref>
In the basement below the [[Steinway]] piano showroom in New York City, a selection of professional grand pianos are available, so that visiting piano performers playing a recital or doing a [[sound recording]] can select the instrument with their preferred sound.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/30/nyregion/steinway-piano-showroom-is-moving-to-a-new-home-in-midtown.html |title=Changing Keys, Steinway Piano Store Will Relocate in Midtown |last=Barron |first=John |date=October 29, 2014 |work=The New York Times |access-date=September 4, 2017 |quote=Steinway plans to use the space beneath the showroom the way it has long used the basement on 57th Street, as a destination for concert pianists who can try different instruments and choose one for their recitals or recording sessions.}}</ref>
===Violin family=== Another specialty shop is the "violin shop", which, despite its name, often sells various violin family instruments (violin, viola, cello and often double bass, and the bows, strings, [[rosin]], chinrests, and other accessories used with these instruments). Violin shops are often operated by [[luthier]]s (violinmakers) who make violin family instruments and bows for sale. Luthiers also do maintenance and repairs on violin family instruments and bows.
According to ''PBS Newshour'', one US violinmaker who sells his instruments is combining his extensive knowledge of centuries-old violin-building techniques with 2010s-era technology such as "[[CT scan]]s" and "3D lasers", which are giving him new insights into his violin design and construction approaches.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/violinmaker-uses-ct-scans-3d-lasers-hone-craft/ |title=Violinmaker uses CT scans, 3D lasers to hone craft |last=Kargbo |first=Connie |date=June 21, 2014 |website=''pbs.org'' |publisher=PBS Newshour |access-date=September 5, 2017 }}</ref>
===Sheet music=== [[Sheet music]] stores sell printed classical music for songs, instrumental solo pieces, [[chamber music]], and scores for major symphonies and choral works, along with instrumental method books, "etudes" (studies) and graded musical exercises. Many sheet music stores also carry printed music songs for [[popular music]] genres such as rock, pop and musical theatre including individual songs and collections of songs grouped by artist, musical, or genre. Music for guitarists or electric bass players may be in [[tabulature]] notation, which depicts where on the instrument the performer should play a line. In the 2010s, sheet music stores often sell legal, copyright-compliant [[jazz]] [[fake book]]s. Sheet music stores often carry some practice accessories, such as [[metronome]]s, [[music stand]]s and [[tuning fork]]s.
===Other single category stores=== Specialized music stores that sell only guitars, only basses or only drums are more likely to be found in major cities. Guitar and bass-focused stores typically sell instruments and the amplifiers and [[effects unit|effects pedals]] used with these instruments.
===Pro audio=== {{Main|Professional audio store}} Pro audio stores sell and in many cases, rent [[sound reinforcement system]] components, [[PA system]]s, [[microphone]]s and other audio gear. Some stores also rent "backline" musical gear, such as [[stage piano]]s and [[bass amp]]s.
===Organ stores=== Prior to the widespread availability of lightweight electronic [[clonewheel organ]]s in the 1980s and 1990s that emulate the sound of a heavy, electromechanical [[Hammond organ]], many cities had organ stores which sold large electric and electronic [[theatre organ]]s and [[spinet organ]]s made by Hammond, Lowrey and other manufacturers. These organs were sold for use in private homes and in churches; electric and electronic organs were popular for churches, because they cost significantly less than a [[pipe organ]].
==Used stores== [[Image:Acoustic bass guitar 1.jpg|thumb|right|180px|A music store display showing an acoustic bass guitar and a variety of bass "combo" amplifiers and speaker cabinets.]]
Some music stores sell used, [[Vintage music equipment|vintage or collectible instruments and sound gear]], often using a [[consignment]] model, in which the store only pays the seller for her instrument when it is sold. Even though there has been a major shift towards the use of electronic and digital instruments and sound gear in the 2000s, there is still a strong interest in vintage instruments amongst musicians who play [[blues]], [[roots rock]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]] and [[indie rock]]. Vintage instruments that are sought out include 1950s and 1960s [[Hammond organ]]s, [[Fender Bassman]] amps and electric guitars, 1970s [[Fender Rhodes]] electric pianos and old analog effects, such as 1970s and 1980s [[stompbox]] pedals. Stores that mostly sell used equipment may also sell some new merchandise, such as new [[guitar string]]s, [[patch cord]]s and mic cables. Conversely, some stores that mostly sell new equipment may also sell some vintage, used equipment (typically a small number of high-priced collectible instruments).
==Online stores== In the 2000s, some music stores sell their instruments and sound gear through a website that contains digital photos of the equipment, which are grouped into categories (e.g., electric guitars, amplifiers, PA gear). Each photo of a product is accompanied by the name and model number of each item, a description of each product's features and the price. The sophistication of online music stores varies. Some online music stores have a single photo of the item, the product name and price, and a few bullets about the features. On the other hand, some online music stores have interactive [[Web 2.0]] features, such as 360-degree [[virtual reality]]-style images of the products, in which the viewer can "turn" the product around to see the back and sides, online comments sections where customers can review their purchases and additional music-related content, such as articles on musical instruments or sound gear written by store staff. Patrons pay electronically at online music stores using a credit card, [[PayPal]] or other electronic payment systems. The goods are shipped through the mail or by express delivery companies such as [[FedEx]]. Some music stores sell their products solely online. In other cases, some stores operate both a "bricks and mortar" store (or chain) and an online store.
==See also== * [[Professional audio store]]s primarily sell [[sound reinforcement system]] equipment, but some also rent "backline" instruments such as [[stage piano]]s and [[bass amplifier]]s
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Music industry}}
[[Category:Music industry]] [[Category:Musical instruments]] [[Category:Music technology]] [[Category:Sound production technology]] [[Category:Sound recording technology]] [[Category:Musical instrument retailers]] [[Category:Shops]]

{{BLP sources|date=January 2008}} [[File:Per Stig Møller-2011-09-03.jpg|thumb|Per Stig Møller in September 2011]] [[File:29-3 05 Fámjin Per Stig Møller og Lagmanden.jpg|thumb|Per Stig Møller (left) and Jóannes Eidesgaard in Fámjin before signing the contract about Faroese-Danish relations in foreign policy]] '''Per Stig Møller''' ({{IPA-da|peɐ̯ sdi ˈmølɐ}}, informal: '''Per Stig'''; born August 27, 1942 in [[Frederiksberg]]) is a Danish politician. He was a member of the [[Folketing]] (Danish national parliament) for the [[Conservative People's Party (Denmark)|Conservative People's Party]] from 1984 until 2015, and was [[Minister for the Environment (Denmark)|Minister for the Environment]] from December 18, 1990 to January 24, 1993 as part of the [[Cabinet of Poul Schlüter IV]] and Foreign Minister from November 27, 2001 to February 23, 2010 as part of the [[Cabinet of Anders Fogh Rasmussen I]], [[Cabinet of Anders Fogh Rasmussen II|II]] and [[Cabinet of Anders Fogh Rasmussen III|III]], and [[Cabinet of Lars Løkke Rasmussen I|the first Cabinet of Lars Løkke Rasmussen]]. From February 23, 2010 to October 3, 2011 he was [[Minister for Culture (Denmark)|Minister for Culture]].
Per Stig Møller is the son of the former [[Finance Minister of Denmark|Finance Minister]] [[Poul Møller (politician)|Poul Møller]] and journalist [[Lis Møller]], who were both Members of Parliament.
== Education == Per Stig Møller completed his [[master's degree]] in [[comparative literature]] at the [[University of Copenhagen]] in 1967, and was awarded a ''dr.phil.'' ([[higher doctorate]]) in 1973 for his thesis ''[[Conrad Malte-Brun|Malte-Brun]]s litterære kritik og dens plads i transformationsprocessen mellem klassicisme og romantik i fransk litteraturhistorie 1800-1826'' (Eng.: ''Literary criticism of Malte-Brun and its position in the transformation process between classicism and romanticism in French history of literature 1800-1826'').
==Non-political career== *1973 - 1974: Editor of culture in [[Danmarks Radio]]. *1974 - 1976: Lecturer at the [[University of Paris]]. *1974, 1976 - 1979: Vice president (souschef) at the department of culture and society at Danmarks Radio. *1979 - 1984: Working with the program manager at Danmarks Radio. *1985 - 1986: Vice president of ''Radiorådet'', the leading organ of Danmarks Radio which is appointed by Folketinget. *1986 - 1987: President of ''Radiorådet''. *1984 - 2001: Commentator at the newspaper [[Berlingske Tidende]].
==Political career== *1983 - 1989: President of [[Folkeligt Oplysningsforbund]]. *1984 – 2015: Member of [[Folketinget]] for the [[Conservative People's Party (Denmark)|Conservative People's Party]]. *1985 - 1998: Member of ''hovedbestyrelsen'', the leadership of the Conservative People's Party. *1987 - 2001: Member of the [[Council of Europe]]. *1990 - 1993: [[Minister for the Environment (Denmark)|Minister for the Environment]] in the [[Cabinet of Poul Schlüter IV]]. *1994 - 2001: Member of [[Udenrigspolitisk Nævn]], the committee for foreign policy. *1994 - 1996: President of [[Sikkerhedspolitisk Udvalg]], the committee of security. *1997 - 1998: Leader of the Conservative People's Party, succeeding [[Hans Engell]]. He resigned after a poor result in the [[Danish parliamentary election, 1998|election in 1998]]. *1998 - 2001: Foreign policy spokesman for the Conservative People's Party. *2001 - 2010: [[Foreign Minister of Denmark]] *2010–2011: [[Culture Minister of Denmark]] *2011–2011: [[List of Ministers for Ecclesiastical Affairs of Denmark|Minister for Ecclesiastical Affairs of Denmark]]
==Bibliography== *''Synspunkter i konservatismen'' (anthology) (1968) *''Antikleksikon'' (with [[Preben Hasselbalch]] and [[Jens Winther]]) (1970) *''La Critique dramatique et littéraire de Malte-Brun'' (1971) *''Utopi og virkelighed'' (with [[Søren Krarup]] and [[Ebbe Reich]]) (1973) *''[[Conrad Malte-Brun|Malte-Brun]]s litterære kritik og dens plads i transformationsprocessen mellem klassicisme og romantik i fransk litteraturhistorie 1800-1826'' (Doctor of Philosophy|Ph. D. thesis) (1973) *''[[Léopold Sédar Senghor]]: Mod en ny civilisation'' (commentary) (1973) *''Tøger Reenberg: Ars Poetica. Digte mellem to tider'' (commentary) (1973) *''Erotismen'' (1973) *''København-Paris t/r'' (1973) *''Tværsnit 1790'' (anthology) (1974) *''På Sporet af det forsvundne Menneske'' (1976) *''Forfatternes Danmarkshistorie'' (editor) (1977) *''Livet i Gøgereden'' (1978) *''Fra Tid til Anden'' (1979) *''Forfatternes kulturhistorie'' (editor) (1979) *''Tro, Håb og Fællesskab'' (1980) *''Forfatternes forfatterhistorie'' (editor) (1980) *''Midt i Redeligheden'' (1981) *''[[George Orwell|Orwell]]s Håb og Frygt'' (1983) *''Nat uden Daggry'' (1985) *''Mulighedernes Samfund'' (with [[Bertel Haarder]] and [[Tom Høyem]]) (1985) *''Stemmer fra Øst'' (1987) *''Historien om Estland, Letland og Litauen'' (1990) *''Kurs mod Katastrofer?'' (1993) *''Miljøproblemer'' (1995) *''Den naturlige Orden - Tolv år der flyttede Verden'' (1996) *''Spor. Udvalgte Skrifter om det åbne Samfund og dets Værdier'' (1997) *''Magt og Afmagt'' (1999) *''[[Kaj Munk|Munk]]'' (2000) *''Mere [[Kaj Munk|Munk]]'' (2003)
==References== {{commons}} *[http://www.ft.dk/Folketinget/findMedlem/KFPESM.aspx CV] - From the official website of [[Folketinget]].
